Jing is hilarious. There is a language barrier at times, but she will explain information repeatedly until it is completely clear to the entire class. She teaches to the test and there will be very few surprises overall. I am not a math person at all, but found her class entertaining and easy because of the way she taught.
Funniest teacher ever. Are you happy with result? ARE YOU HAPPY? Hilarious. Fantastic teacher. If you get her be sure to give her a high five at some point. It'll be the best experience of your life.
Final sucked.Do good in first 3 tests.

I had her for Applied Calc II and she's really nice and very helpful. She gives partial credit and is really good at explaining concepts. She can actually be pretty funny, too. I would definitely recommend her.

MATH 1210.comment: Ala is the man. Have had him for Applied calc 1 and 2. Definitely take his class if you have to take calculus. He is helpful and kind, and often an interesting lecturer. A bit alternative too, but in a good way. Super chill, and always ready to help.

Hands down my favorite math teacher I have ever had. He's super funny and relatable to students. Ala is great at explaining things in his own terms and he is always available for help if you ask. Plus, he tends to be a pretty lenient grader which is definitely a plus. Would recommend him as a teacher to everyone.
He explains concepts in a way that everyone can understand and is very good at clarifying if a student has a question. And he's hilarious.
might lowk be the worst teacher at hamilton, no joke. she is snarky and weird and doesnt teach. I HATE THIS CLASS
sucks at explaing math. did not need to hear someone talk about figure skating all day when i'm desperately trying to bring my grade back to an A
this class singlehanded made me hate math and stats. i regret not taking other classes instead of this. DONT TAKE HER CLASS!!
bad
Gives too much hw and is bad at explaining math

She's nice and very eager to help, but a bit awkward at times. The lectures are bit too focused on theorems and I think they could be explained in much shorter ways (plus her handwriting is hard to read sometimes). She did make a large effort to be available after class though...
Homework is given by a variety of platforms so it's a little hard to keep track of every single one of them. A great person, however, their teaching style isn't so great.
If you can't teach the material to yourself, find another teacher.

Don't take his class. Doesn't take teaching seriously in the slightest, and UVA is actually his side job. Main focus is being funny. When asked for clarification, he sometimes said he didn't know how else he could say it. His style felt like "teach yourself or good luck." Had to get tutored on the side often. Got points taken off for insane things.
Awful teacher. Stay away at all costs. Worst teacher I have ever had.

Bad. She faces the board the whole class, speaks really quietly, and does not explain concepts well at all. Her "lectures" are hard to follow and I never feel prepared for exams. She is a really nice person and is available outside of class if you seek her help. However, I would not recommend her ESPECIALLY if you aren't familiar with CALC.

Sue He is a terrible teacher. She reads off her notes and does not face the class. She writes out everything and avoids difficult questions that you ask. She also assigns a ridiculous amount of homework. If you have no prior experience with calculus then either hire a tutor or find another teacher
He always teaches harder subjects comparing to other TAs. very unhelpful. much more hw comparing to other classes. dont take him never

I thought Professor Bradshaw was very good at explaining calculus concepts. I took Calc in high school but not the AP, so it was a really easy A for me, but he really solidified the logic of things I had just memorized before. He uses lots of examples.

This professor/GA's lectures are often disorganized and confusing and he often forgets to teach some material covered on the exams. You never know what assignments are due because he is never clear on anything and just sends out a bunch of random emails. If you have a choice, do not take a class with him.
Great teacher!
Keith Leitmeyer is literally the worst educator I have ever come upon in my entire life. Do everything in your power to stay away.

Graber is a very fair professor who is clear in his lectures without being too dry and boring. Very likable because he is so nice and willing to help even the most reluctant math student.He also provides ample opportunities for the students to meet with him to work through problems and answer any questions. Great teacher!!!
Extremely sweet and helpful. Office hours very helpful for those who are not great with math.
Extremely nice teacher, really care about the students. Passionate and clear. Office hour is very helpful.

Many of my friends took the same class with different grad students, and from talking with them I am incredibly glad I had Josh. He really wanted us to do well, and helped by curving tests and providing extra credit (which other teachers did not do). I thought he was very clear and good at explaining problems. Also willing to help you after class.

Josh is the sweetest teacher. Explains new concepts in interesting ways... it really helped me understand it. And his drawings on the board are awesome. He makes nerdy math jokes - you won't find that in many other classes. Josh is rare! Take his class. He's very helpful and it actually made me look forward to calculus class. :)

Pretty awkward and not the most enthusiastic teacher, but he's a LOT better than most of the other grad students teaching the course. He's really helpful if you ask questions, otherwise he'll just keep moving through the material. Pretty funny, if you can appreciate nerdy-math-grad-student humor.
Nice guy but he struggles to be a teacher.  He knows his stuff and his helpful when you go in to see him.

Pappas is one of the best instructors you can have! He not only knows his stuff, but is also a great teacher and explains the material well. He also has a way of foreseeing the mistakes students often make and warns you before hand. I used to hate calc, he has sort of changed my mind now. He's also very friendly. Go to office hours-very helpful!

I still do not understand how Sean is paid to teach at UVA. Worst teacher at the University by far. He took a subject I used to be interested in and made me hate it. Switch to a different teacher immediately.

She's a really fun and nice math teacher who understands students' mentality. She gives out written homework and WebAssign every week but they aren't usually too hard. She kinda grades written homework hard but she has a reason behind this. It really helps to understand the ACTUAL concept. Only downside to her: She doesn't give out A+s to anyone.

STAT 2120.comment: I ended up really liking this class. Lectures were hilarious. Homework could be hard, but the labs were extremely helpful, and I wish I'd started going to help labs earlier! Tests were very hard, but the curve made grades decent. Professor was very helpful and nice and made sure to go at a pace everyone could keep up with. This was a great class!

Really funny and a genuinely nice guy. I enjoy his sense of humor but if you're the type of person who prefers more traditional academic lecturers he might not be your favorite. Very helpful outside of class and keeps the lectures as interesting as I can imagine an introductory statistics course can be. Not too difficult either if you do the hw.
Professor Abdelbaki is the coolest dude ever. He's so chill, and seems so approachable. I enjoyed listening to his corny grad studentish jokes.

Down to earth guy. Genuinely wants you to learn. His lectures are useful if you have read the chapters before the class. Webworks (approx. 20q's) are due every Sunday and could take from 1-4hr. Tests are challenging, but if you do your hw and readings, they're no biggie.

Holt is good - lectures are easy to understand, he's very generous with lab/quiz drops, and he is kind & cares about students doing well. Overall, class is pretty easy, made up of just exams, labs and quizzes. If you have to take this class, I recommend taking it with Holt. Very low homework load. All info is on slides, attendance not mandatory.

I wish I had worked harder in high school and gained admission to a better university and program, UVA statistics is a barrel scraping program with pretensions and bad prospects. I am ashamed to have graduated from this program and do not put the degree on the resume (I also studied ba computer science). As for the professor jeffrey holt … 🤣
Very good at teaching

Nice and cheerful guy. The class is well structure. I just read the slides, did a ton of practice quizzes, and read the book if I didn't understand something, and I got an A. Really useful information too ?I learned a lot.
He's very clear and straightforward. This is by far the easiest and least demanding 4 credit course I have taken.

If you're enrolled in this course, it's likely not by choice. Given the pre-requitory nature of this class, most want to sail through as seemlessly as possible, and Holt is certainly the professor with which to do it. Attending lecture is completely optional, grading is fair (if not forgiving) and exams are very manageable if you put in the effort.

Prof. Martinet is really just a bad teacher. She does not explain concepts well at all and will leave you more confused than before. She just reads off the slides. You basically have to teach yourself everything. As a STAT major, I found her to also be a very bad advisor and she is very difficult to reach. Doesn't answer emails even.
Just don't take her class if you can manage to get out of it. I have never understood a concept better from her explanations. Get ready to teach Stats to yourself.
Aviod her at any costs!!!
Terrible professor

Personally, she's cool. As a teacher, another story. She literally reads the slides, which all students have access to online making attendance pointless. Textbook is a must have seeing that you will basically be teaching yourself the course. Homework is EASY, and so are the labs. THEN the exam questions make you wonder if you're in the right room.

Martinet is an incredibly ineffective lecturer. She basically just stands still in one spot the entire lecture and reads the power point slides (which also make no sense).  She doesn't do useful practice problems, so when the homework and test roll around you have no idea how to do anything.  Avoid her at all costs, she is truly an awful professor.

Not a bad teacher, but she pretty much read through her slides so lecture seemed pretty pointless. Only reason to go is the learning catalytics participation grade. I hate statistics so I didn't enjoy the class and thought it was really hard, but its not like its impossible to do well. Just as long as you put in the work. She doesn't curve tests.

Horrible teacher. All she does is read slides. The book is old and convoluted as are her slides. She never teachers graphing calculator functions and only teaches in excel formulas even though all test are graphing calculator.
Reads her own slides only. Explanations of topics only seem to further complicate them. Nice enough person, awful teacher.
worst class. bad teaching.

I honestly kinda liked this class. But Prof. Woo is a great teacher who really cares about students and is very helpful in office hours. Labs are easy, just show up. HW is not too bad and make sure to do practice problems he sends out to prepare for exams. I have heard is one of the more annoying Stat classes, so it gets cooler after 2120!
Woo is a really caring guy. I really struggled in his class but he grades in a way that you can still do well if that's the case, and is always around to help outside of class if you need it.

Prof. Woo is awesome. His material is very straight forward, his lectures are to the point and are very beneficial to attend because he gives relevant examples that help a ton with homework and studying for exams. He provides everything you need to get an A in his class just show up and do the work it's not super hard plus he's witty.

I loved Justin's class overall I just wasn't a huge fan of the layout of the class. Basically you use R Studio for the lab assignments, but we are not allowed to use R on the tests. So when the tests come up, we have no idea what to expect because there are not practice problems we can look back on.

Prof. Weinstock is nice, but most people just look at the slides that he posts instead of attending lectures, which works just as well. If you want an A in the class, I would recommend going to your lab sections because you can check your answers with the other students and TAs and basically get free 100s on the lab assignments

Justin is the guy. Super approachable and somehow makes stat lectures somewhat interesting, which in my mind is borderline impossible. If you want an A you'll get it. His slides are super straight forward, labs and take home quizzes should be automatic As when taken seriously. Also, he has a ton of office hours. Overall goated.

A very likable and kind guy. Lectures are taught with very visually simple presentations in the same fashion every time, but this can make the content clear. Lots of opportunities to drop bad grades. Lecture slides are posted, so if you didn't want to you don't ever have to attend class. Lab assignments make sure you know material as you go along.

Worst STAT 2120 teacher at UVA.  Tests were tricky and were nothing like anything addressed in the lectures or homework problems, especially the conceptual questions, which were very hit or miss.  Lectures are pointless as he only reads off of the slides.

Spitzner is absolutely terrible. Take this with anyone else. You won't learn a thing from lecture because he puts the textbook into PowerPoint and reads straight off the slides. Don't bother going to lecture.

Definitely a tough class. Lectures are truly confusing - he doesn't explain sufficiently or clearly enough - hence pointless. Just make sure you understand the examples and homework questions, 'cause exams are similar, but concept (definition) questions are really hard, and usually a hit or miss. Homework and labs take up a lot of time too.

ECON 2060.comment: 3 Total Grades --> All EXAMS. He's a nice professor, but unfortunately a senile old man who gives conflicting information which is tough when the calls is all exams.

Absolutely phenomenal lectures. He's a great storyteller and makes all the topics he covers surprisingly accessible. Get ready to be really stressed about his three exams, but it's worth it for the lectures. Attendance isn't mandatory, but if you don't go to every class you'll be in a pretty tough spot.

I loved Mr. Thomas. He is the greatest teacher of all time. I never went to class, and he would send me recordings of his lectures. He was always concerned with our well-being. I highly recommend this easy, fun, and useful.

I took American Economic History with him during Fall 2022 and I will say I didn't feel prepared enough for the class. This professor really knows his history but THIS IS A HISTORY CLASS. I am a double Econ major and I took this class seing Econ 2060, but you only need to know supply and demand curves for this course. Take if you like history.
Amazing lecturer and super interesting class though the he grades the tests extremely hard.  Certainly must do the outside readings extremely in detail if you want a good grade on the tests.

HIUS 2060.comment: Two recommendations for success in this challenging class: 1) Attend every lecture and take good notes. 2) Recruit three or four fellow students to form a study/exam review group. Do this before the first exam! I only did this for the subsequent exams, and my first exam sunk my grade. We all take notes differently, and comparing them is invaluable.

This is more of a history class than an economics class, though Mr. Thomas is well versed in both. There are four exams, but the third exam and the final are taken back-to-back during the final exam period. There is quite a bit of reading, and skipping lectures is not advised. Exams are tough and strictly graded, but the lectures are fascinating.

DO NOT take this class if you do not have to. The whole grade is based off of just 3 exams and the final is worth 50% of your grade. The TAs grade rather harshly as well. If you want to do well in this class it will require A LOT of time each, and that is time that you will probably end up using for more important classes.

Professor Thomas is a very approachable professor and his lectures are quite interesting. However, he has no power points, dose not record lectures, and bases your grade only on THREE tests, with a final worth 50%. The amount of reading is immense and the textbook is REQUIRED. Grading criteria is tough and is very subjective to the grader.

Prof Thomas is a really good lecturer/story teller and this was probably one of my favorite classes this semester. That being said, there were a few issues: 1) Our entire grade is based off of 3 tests 2) You have to do A LOT of reading 3) He didn't give us any info on the final until one week before 4) this is def a history course, not an econ one

I took History of U.S. Economy, found the class very interesting and Mark was very helpful. If I go history major he'll be one of the main reasons why. Go to his office hours, for clarification and just to get to know him cuz he is a nice guy and very cool. The class is not easy- reading is important and grading is tough- but its worthwhile.

HIUS 2061.comment: Mark Thomas is a REALLY great lecturer and his class was very interesting. However, taking this class as a first year who only had some interest in American Economic History was a huge mistake. His tests are incredibly difficult and can cover a huge amount of material, so you never know what is on them. It is really challenging to get a good grade.

Professor Thomas gives the greatest lectures of any professor I've ever had. The entire class is graded by three exams and a lot is covered in the lectures so you don't want to miss a single one. Tough class with a ton of reading but the professor makes all of it worth it. Can't recommend this class enough.

I learned a lot in a class that should have put even his colleagues to sleep. Prof. Thomas was interesting and had good humor in his lectures. However, the entire grade for the class is based on written exams that he grades somewhat harshly. Don't expect an A or A-plus without a LOT of work- my B+ cost me lots of reading and note-taking.

Mark Thomas is a fantastic lecturer. He is very passionate about economic history and gives dynamic lectures featuring both in depth historical analysis and story telling to put the information in context. You need to pay close attention in lecture to do well but I enjoyed his lectures immensely so that was never an issue.

Mark Thomas is a great lecturer that you can tell really cares about the subject. However, the tests were incredibly difficult, and graded harshly. Definitely not a class to take if you want to save, keep, or improve your GPA.
I cannot recommend this class highly enough. Mark Thomas is absolutely fantastic; a very notes-intensive course that requires a lot of reading. I looked forward to his lectures every other day.
American Economic History- very interesting course, sparked my interest in economics. Mark Thomas is a great professor, good sense of humor too, funny.

Each lecture is like a story. Mr. Thomas is a great lecturer and is also extremely helpful in office hours. He cares about his students, and will remember your name! Definitely take History of the U.S. Economy.
An excellent lecturer. I learned so much from every class. The tests were difficult and you really had to study.

HIST 3411.comment: Mr Thomas is a great professor, definitely not an easy A class but completely worth it. Just pay attention in lecture and you'll do fine.

ARH 3710.comment: Louis Nelson is a wonderful professor. I am a STEM major who took his 3701 class for a requirement and thought it would be a bore. I was very wrong. He is an amazing and enthusiastic lecturer who is very invested in what he does. I highly recommend that anybody who is interested in ARCH or HIS or needs a requirement takes his class.

Louis is easily the best professor I've had so far at UVA (4 semesters). You can tell he's passionate about the course material and  the lectures are amazing! That being said, the readings are pretty intense (although no textbook!) and you really get out of the class what you put into it.

ARTH 2753.comment: Prof Nelson knows what he's talking about and is a pretty good lecturer. That being said, he structures his classes horribly, only have 4 assessments, making the midterm weigh a lot, and only have 1 grade in before the final had to be taken. Also he uses norm-reference curved grading in a subjective class which absolutely makes no sense.

ARH 2700.comment: Seriously, jump at any opportunity to learn from or work with Professor Nelson. The way that he structures his courses is clearly masterful -- you'll learn heaps from lecture alone because this man knows how to TEACH. Be prepared for one of those rare classes that truly reminds you why educational institutions are sacred and indispensable things.

He's really charismatic and he's not afraid to joke around. There are very few assignments (three short papers, a midterm, and a final) so you NEED to put time into studying for them. We analyzed all sides of Thomas Jefferson and I'm glad that Nelson didn't make TJ out to be a saint. Moral of the class was that TJ was a complex hypocrite.

AMST 2753.comment: Amazing professor. Make sure to do all the reading and take notes during the lectures. The individual portion of the main group project for the class I took (ARTH 2753) was very stressful and difficult, but if you seek the right guidance and work hard in the class its possible to get an A. Great lecturer and great course!

Professor Nelson is a really interesting guy. His lectures are great - very engaging and easy to follow. It's obvious he has a true passion for what he's doing as well as an excellent understanding of it. I would really recommend his Arts&Cultures of the Slave South class with Professor McInnis. The two really teach well together!

ARH 3500.comment: Professor Nelson is one of my favorite professors I have had so far in college. I am not an architecture major, but found his class engaging and his talks very interesting. He is a fair but tough grader. There was a lot of reading and writing in my class, but he gives you plenty of useful feedback on papers. He is particularly a stickler on prose.

STAT 2020.comment: i am currently preparing for the final. i have always been good with math. never taken a stats course before though. as i am studying, i am downing as many redbulls as possible. not so i can have the enrgy to stay up longer, but with the hopes that the next is my last and the heart attack will just come already.

Professor Ferrara is a very nice person but I found that the mandatory lectures required you to teach yourself the content outside of class. Her grading is inconsistent and she will take points off for very minor things. She does not accommodate for illness or late submissions and I found it difficult to navigate her grading expectations.

Did not like Maria at all. Teaching yourself everything from a jumbled slideshow/speaker notes. Lectures are not helpful at all (she really only answers questions and then has you do group work; doesn't teach you anything). She literally repeats the easiest points and skims over the harder stuff. I've taken stats before and never struggled so much.

Fairly easy class with mandatory attendance. Overall grade is not just exams which is helpful. Reverse teaching style where you are expected to teach yourself outside of lecture. The lecture is just time to work on more problems and highlight the key ideas.

Fair and quick grader, decently accessible outside of class. Lots of homework. Flip classroom = teach yourself! Class time is devoted to group work (easy grades, though). DO THE PRACTICE TESTS. They accurately represent the exams- Maria doesn't sucker punch. Labs aren't painful. Just do the pre-labs.

*I wouldn't take as a first statistics class!*

Professor Ferrara's class was rather boring and really emphasized learning outside of class (AKA you are teaching yourself the entirety of the course content prior to lecture and just briefly reviewing in lecture as you and your group members struggle through practice problems). While exams are hard, if you go to class/lab you will do well!

I was very unhappy with this professor. Do not expect her to be accomodating of illness, even something as severe as a concussion. She is very lazy and will not go out of her way to care for students. Apart from that, class is easy to succeed in. Lectures are incredibly boring, though. I'd say they were useless if it weren't for the mandatory work

Prof. Ferrara is a great teacher and the learning material is not difficult. She doesn't lecture though, we just do group work during the lecture time and have to take the notes on our own outside of class. Makes me wish she lectured since she's really great at explaining everything. Labs were easy and there were plenty of office hours.

This lady made my friend drive all the way to school just because she didnt want to cancel class the week of thanksgiving break. Like girl sit down.. she thought she ate thats why nobody showed up to class
Mediocre class. Learned RStudio, but nothing special.
Very thorough lectures (almost too thorough, she talks a lottt but I personally found it helpful). If you do all of the work and watch all of the lecture videos, you will definitely do well.

Notes are all taught in recorded video lectures (at least my semester). Makes it difficult to ask questions and clarify. Synchronous classes felt kind of pointless. Material was somewhat interesting sometimes, but nothing exciting. She is also very particular about format and grading. I didn't enjoy going to class, but didn't hate it.

Maria is very straightforward and will give you exactly what you expect. Statistics is not that difficult of a course, and she makes sure to cover the things you really need to know. She is very transparent about what will be on the exams. There is weekly online homework that is not difficult. Her exams are short, so each question is worth a lot.

I never got the textbook, just took good notes on her lectures and paid attention to the homework and labs and got an A. Lectures are pretty clear and not too text-heavy. Exams aren't too bad if you study enough
Great instructor. Clear, straightforward grading guidelines and reasonable exams. ALWAYS available outside of class if you need help.

Maria is a pretty good lecturer and her class makes sense. She is upfront about the fact that there is no curve but most exams averaged about 77% mean anyway. If you pay attention, do the graded homework assignments, and study, this is a fairly easy class provided you're good at math.

Maria is a really nice person, but not the clearest lecturer. Her slides are very clear, however, so it's not that important. She often seemed a little frazzled in class, but I think it was also because students only take this class for a requirement. Group projects were obnoxious, but there's only 2. TAKE THIS OVER STAT 2120!

Rebecca's lectures are dry and boring. She mainly reads off of powerpoints that are posted online before class and works through some practice problems with the class. While the class is boring and hard to sit through, she is sooo knowledgable about statistics. She is very smart, this class is just too easy to be interesting.

Prof. Hehn is really nice, sweet, and good at explaining things. Office hours are helpful and there isn't much hw, just WebAssign each week and lab. A lot of the practice must be done on your own but the exams are similar to the practice problems done in class, more so than the practice exam. She's enthusiastic but students aren't. I recommend her!
I dont want to be more specific.

Definitely take STAT 2020 with Jessica. She is a professor and Maria is a grad student. The class is easy for people who have taken statistics in high school, but more difficult for those who did not. Go to office hours for help with homework, group projects, and exam review. She is very approachable and always willing to help.

STAT 4160.comment: Professor Ferrara is nice enough, but not a very good lecturer. Her slides often had errors that she would have to go back and change after lecture and she was unable to answer some questions clearly (or at all). She was a harsh grader, considering how poorly she taught the material, and was inconsistent with her grading across assignments.

EVSC 1010.comment: Do not take this class if you think it will be easy. Yes there is no final and there are only 6 tests which are take home but they are very tricky. The material isnt hard but the tests questions are confusing and will have questions about the color of his favorite bird. (Im serious) Even if you know the bird and color you may still get it wrong.

He is very disorganized and tests on very specific topics from lecture. Often used pop quizzes to curb low attendance to class. Only reason students took the class was the fact the grade was made up of six take-home exams. Overall, I do not suggest this class.

Lerdau is a lovely, entertaining, and goofy person. His class is less great. He is disorganized, and grades only on tests. His tests are confusing, but you eventually get the hang of his wording and it gets easier. Take notes on the slides ahead of time because he flies through them in lecture. Don't take this if you are looking for an easy class.
Four open note tests, no final, one quiz per lecture, test and quiz questions taken right from lecture slides, easiest A ever taken

4 open note tests, short quiz after every lecture, usually with questions phrased exactly like they were on the slides, all true/false or multiple choice. Slides are posted, take good notes and it's impossible not to get an A. Really easy but also really interesting and enjoyable.
This class was very easy and very interesting, whether you have a background in environmental science or not. Office hours were always very helpful before exams even with the class size being so big.

Do the quizzes so you can get extra credit on the test. Straight forward class, read the lecture slides (which he sends to you) and you will do well on test. Extra credit quizzes also help answer questions on test.
Whole class is based off of 3 exams. The lectures are boring. Professor is a good person but his structure of the class is lazy. Very unsatisfied

Don't buy the textbook! As long as you go to class and study a minimal amount, you should pass with at least a B. Going to class is more important in the end than in the beginning as the tests get harder and harder. Also he'll have opportunities to for you to get extra points on random days, so even though class is boring, GO!

Class is made up of three exams. Exams get harder. Class attendance isn't mandatory but if you want a good grade, you should go. To study, read over his Powerpoints and look at the terms on the study guide. Class is a basic high school science class, so go to class and study a day in advance of exams and you should get at least a B.

Class is boring.  The exams are very difficult and require memorization.  Questions are written in a way to really confuse the students.  There are only 3 exams and he really doesn't care if you do well or not.
Very good teacher.  Excellent explanations. Extremely flexible with office hours. Keeps you up to date and wants students to succeed.  1010 is very easy.

One of the best professors I've had.  Very helpful and flexible.  Attendance isn't required and the class itself isn't very difficult.  All the test questions come right from his class slides and he gives you outlines with the topics that will be on the test.  If you have the opportunity, definitely take a class with him

DO NOT TAKE. If you need to take EVSC 1010, wait until the spring when she is NOT teaching. Professor Blum is unclear, confusing, and highly inarticulate. No student should receive a D+ in an introductory course, but somehow Blum made that possible for me. I studied hard, went to class, and went to office hours. Her tests are very difficult.

There aren't any assignments in this class, but there are 4 exams (the lowest grade gets dropped) plus a final, which are mainly based off of the lectures. She does post the slides online for students, but she changes them. So she will show some slides in class, that we don't have. She does read off of the slides quite often. I didn't care for EVSC

I enjoyed Professor Blum. She is passionate about what she is teaching, but to do well you must go to the lectures and take good notes. If you do that you don't need to read the textbook. She is always ready to help and will spend however long it takes to make sure you do. If you want to do well, you will. The concepts are not hard.

Avoid this professor. Take this course in the spring with the other instructor. She is very unclear, her slides are disorganized and she creates no incentives for her students to do better. There is no curve even though the class average for most of her tests is 70.

While it is obvious that Blum has a lot of interest in the course material it is often hard to follow her lectures.  The slides that she posts only contain pictures so it is impossible to skip lecture and try to catch up by looking at the slides.  She gives zero guidance on what to study for exams. She's tough but not terrible.

She really isn't that bad. She loves the material, though the lectures can be a bit boring. Her tests are based almost completely off the lecture, so go to lecture and take good notes. I got a B+ by cramming the night before for everything. It's really not that bad of a class, and the material isn't that hard.

EVSC 2200.comment: The class is easy (I took EVSC 1010), but the one thing that you should know is he is quite literally the MOST disorganized man. He would mess up the quiz scoring banks, send out the most broken announcements that left everyone confused, and would NEVER respond to an email that you sent out. He's like an emotionally unavailable boyfriend.

I didn't find Professor Lerdau's lectures particularly engaging or informative--I was often confused about which information was necessary and which was supplemental, making it difficult to take effective notes, and his visual aids did not help much. However, he seems like a nice guy who is clearly passionate and knowledgeable in his field.

Honestly the most boring lectures about topics that do not have to be that boring. He admits to trying to trick you on the quizzes and your entire grade is made up of a midterm and a final. He is not helpful during office hours either. At best, he makes jokes sometimes but generally does not try and help his students succeed.

Don't take the class. Don't do it. I also read reviews and didn't think it would be THAT bad--but it was. The ENTIRE course was based on 2 exams; exams that weren't based on the course material that we discussed...just random facts. Unfortunately, there's not other great intro cons ecology class, but whatever you do, dont take the class.

Awful professor. Extremely disorganized. Readings unnecessary. You must be in class because the powerpoints are not helpful at all; take notes on what he says. Cheerful guy, but he is not fit for teaching, nor writing tests. He is delusional in his expectations; it took a month to get midterms back because they were free response and he has 0 TAs.

Professor Smith is a very nice and knowledgeable professor.  Simply, he is a straight-shooter when it comes to tests, and he is a wealth of information in lecture.  With Plants, People and Culture specifically, it definitely is recommended that you attend lecture, but it is not required.

EVSC 3200.comment: Not a good professor, there are very difficult tests, boring lectures. Helps to read the textbook.
I think this guy is actually a pretty good professor and lecturer. He makes the topic interesting and easy to learn, but the tests can be tricky.

He loves what he does which makes it worth taking. Not all that easy. But most of the tests are short response. He is lenient when grading them and if you understand anything about what you are saying he'll give you a good grade.

Professor Lerdau makes an easy class difficult.  His exams either consisted of memorizing every detail off of his lecture slides or "what if" type questions that did not correlate to what he lectured in class.  On our final test he wrote questions that he later admitted were unclear and poorly written.  Avoid taking Lerdau if possible.

The material that he is teaching is not all that difficult to grasp, but his method of teaching is more complicated than it should be. He focuses a lot on the specific equations that define the concepts, which turn out not to be very important. Also, he has not told us our grade on either of the first two tests and its been at least two months.

Awesome lectures-hes very straightforward and the grading criteria is always clear. the class only has 4 grades (multiple choice tests), so not a lot of room for error. No final. He  is very organized and easy to follow. also a super nice guy in general. beware though the multiple choice tests are tricky, not as easy as you'd expect.
An incredibly nice guy and a great lecturer. Definitely take

Tom Smith is undoubtedly an amazing professor. Every lecture was phenomenal and kept me interested the whole way through.  However, tests can be hard and the study guides can be a bit misguiding.  He didn't quite explain what would be on each test, so the first one everyone did pretty well then the second people tanked. Still a great class though!

Awesome teacher.  Subject matter is challenging but Smith makes it understandable.  NOTE: Lab is VERY challenging and takes a lot of effort crammed into a short amount of time.  Lab not recommended if you don't have to take it. TA's run labs.

EVSC 2220.comment: This professor was one of the worst I've had at UVa. He is a very non-engaging professor and expects you to memorize his powerpoints for the exams. His exams are nothing you've seen before and he is a very tough grader. There were only two grades for the semester (2 exams). He is also very snarky and unhelpful in office hours. Avoid this professor.

There isn't a textbook, so he expects you to rely entirely upon his lectures. There were only 2 grades (a midterm and a final). Very unorganized and unclear lecturer. Doesn't write test questions that gauge students' understanding. For the most part they are either trick questions or extremely obscure. Readings are arbitrary.

Very unclear, ramble-y lecture style. Minimalistic slides do not aid comprehension. Snarky and unhelpful during office hours. Would avoid class with Lerdau if possible. Nice guy but terribly boring and unorganized professor.

Professor Lerdau is an extremely unclear lecturer. He thinks that you come to the class already with a good understanding of difficult topics when in reality, most people have not taken an EnviSci class since high school. Consequently, he explains things rather poorly. He is also a tough grader, you essentially need to memorize his lectures.

Bob is a great guy, very funny and he does his best to make the material engaging. However, his powerpoints are ridiculously long and he never has time to get through the details in an effective way. Instead, you're left with hundreds of slides to look at before each test, most of which won't be relevant to the questions asked. Not great overall

To be fair, some people may enjoy Swap's style of lecture: I am not one of those. He is certainly passionate and some find him funny, but I did not.  Swap moves too fast in lecture, but puts the slides up online. His tests are pretty easy, but always include obscure questions. Easy class, but unless you are interested in EVSC, avoid this class.
Professor Swap is a great lecturer and very interested in engaging his students. He's frequently available outside of class and extremely helpful. I definitely recommend taking this class.
Professor Swap is a really cool guy. If you like environmental science, you should definitely take this class. He's really helpful outside of class and his tests aren't hard at all.

CS 4501.comment: Genuinely terrible professor had a pop quiz worth 15% of our grade. Graded harshly and people pulled all nighters trying to do assignments. dont take this class it took years off my life.

I was in Professor Behl's F1/10 Autonomous Racing Course and it was one of the best courses in CS I took during my time at UVA. Prof Behl's lectures are very enjoyable to listen too and he explains the concepts very clearly. You can tell he is an expert in the area of self driving cars.
Some knowledge is out of date, but the whole class is well-designed.
The this class is taught is reading from the slides. We had a very short amount of time for doing group projects and grading was very tough.
This class's grade is largely depend on test and group projects. homework grading is very harsh. No late day. No negotiation. If you submitted late for 1 second, you get 15% off.
Great professor! Challenging class but worth it!

APMA 3120.comment: Lark is one of my favorite professors that I have had. He is likely the smartest person I have taken a class from and he is good at explaining things. Assignments were designed to make sure that you knew and understood the material rather than make you fail. Also go to office hours! Enjoyable to talk to and has lots of cool stories.

He's a fine professor. Nothing special. His lectures are hella boring and I got annoyed that so many were for "cultural edification" that we weren't graded on when I had actual questions about the real material. But, he's not terrible. He has his policies and he sticks to them. He says attendance is mandatory, but do what you want.

The worst teacher I have ever had at UVA. He is slow and boring. Most students took a nap in his class. He hates being challenged and he wont like you after that. Very eregant man. I had to teach everything I know about that class. I got a B but I strongly believe I would of got an A if I was a girl. My girlfriend got an A!!!!!! I thought her every

APMA 3110.comment: No reason to go to class half the time, class is very dry and boring anyway. Other half is quizzes and turning in homework. Two tests & a final, 1 project.
You should change your schedule to get Professor Morris. She's awesome.
Really hard on grading. Have certain kind of favaritism towards certain students. especially for females.

Deep is a good and responsive professor. He teaches Probstat in a way that makes the subject easy to understand. The class is quite easy if you take extra time to do practice problems. He also responds to emails quickly and is generally accommodating.

Two main things that made this class difficult: the subject and this professor. You have to give 100% of your undivided attention (as you should). However, you have to constantly ask for 1-on-1 help. Lecturing a class is clearly not what he's good at. Barely anyone could understand what he's trying to teach us. Better to go to his office hours.

He is definitely one of the most brilliant people on grounds. He is also very helpful during in-class activities and WeBWork (weekly online homework). However, keeping in mind this was his first time teaching an APMA course, his lecture style had little to no effectiveness. Barely a third of the class came. APMA 3110 tests were extremely difficult.

Professor Pisano is a great teacher and a very kind lady. She really knows her material and her office hours are extremely helpful if you are struggling with a concept. She makes occasional computational mistakes in class but nothing that indicates a lack of understanding. She will go the extra mile for you if you need help!

Prob-Stat was terrible with him. He went way to fast through everything and assumed students understood as easily/quickly as he does. Very little help in office hours. His examples are the super-easy kind, such that when you try doing a real problem (HW) you can't find any similarities and apply the methods.
Excellent professor. Well organized and prepared. He's sort of soft-spoken and can be boring at times, but he's great. His tests are hard though and he gives weekly quizzes.

ENGR 1620.comment: QUite interesting to talk to.  He doesnt think his class is the only class we have, very considerate. NO TESTS, just projects and is very easy with his grading

I have mixed feeling for this instructor. On the one hand, I was introduced to a wide range of topics and learned some useful skills. However, he could improve his explanations of new topics. Sometimes he expects us to self-teach, but when we ask questions he looks at us like he thinks we aren't trying.

I don't even know how to describe this class other than unorganized, unhelpful, and one of my least favorite classes I've ever taken. Maiti seems to have little clue to how to actually teach, and have no classroom management skills. He yells at us for not asking questions, but then yells at us for not knowing the answer to the questions we do ask.

Be prepared to devote A LOT of time and work to this class. Instead of learning in a traditional classroom setting, you will actually design and build a functional prototype. Make sure to participate as often as possible for the few times you are in class. There WILL be times when you will want to give up, but overall, this class will be worth it.

Dr Williams is my adviser and in that area he isn't extraordinary. He answers emails promptly. The class was taught entirely by TAs, and including actually building a wooden violin and some minor coding challenges. The midterm was take-home, and a memorization test.

Extremely helpful, easy class, no homework, almost impossible to not get an A. Professor Williams is very nice and wants students to enjoy engineering from a broader perspective. Also emphasizes enjoying life at UVA in general. Very smart and genuine guy.
He's a great guy and has interesting stories, but you never really know what you're supposed to be doing.

Professor Zhigilei was one of the best professors I've had at UVA thus far. He is very caring and considerate towards his students and makes concepts/course content easy and clear to understand. He's also extremely approachable and just an overall delight.

AVOID ASMA FOR ENGR 1620! Look, she's nice one-on-one. However, that alone is not enough to make a class. Much more busywork than other 1620 sections with draconian high-school rules: no phones, mandatory attendance, no talking. Yes, she'll dock your grade. Endless group work (not hard, just way too much of it). In the end, frustrating and futile.

Lewin is a great guy, and really helpful if you go to him. Don't hesitate to ask him for help or to ask questions. Sometimes his 5 minute talks turn into 30 minute talks at the start of class, but usually it's useful.

Professor Holmes has a great sense of humor and I found his class very enjoyable. He is very helpful when it comes to competition ideas and always had entertaining slides and lectures when not in lab.

He is very laid back and lets the students take charge a lot. The class mostly consists of group projects. Only drawback is there are hardly any grades and he takes months to grade the few assignments you actually do. The semester is almost over and I have zero graded assignments handed back and am still clueless as to what my grade in the class is

She's very helpful when you go in for help or ask her questions. She does however give a lot of projects and group work. Her projects are only moderately interesting. She focuses pretty much just on systems engineering and the engineering design process for her intro to engr class.

She is the best teacher ever. The comments below are outdated and irrelevant. She is a kind-hearted, wonderful teacher that obviously loves the students. She does a great job with the material and does not give an excessive amount of writing. She just understands that real engineers have the ability to communicate, as well as build prototypes!!!
I don't know what everyone else is talking about but Susan Donohue is one of the kindest and most helpful professors I've ever had.

I have yet to understand the true purpose of this class. I was under the impression that the objective was to design a project, however, there is an unnecessary overemphasized focus on writing. During the final weeks of the semester, she finally starts freaking out over the project that no one's had the opportunity to focus on. Good luck.

She is the worst teacher I have had in 13 years of schooling. She would make you think ENGR stands for English Grammar. She makes you do about 20 presentations with little design work. She will care more about a title not being centered than the actual material. She will spend 1/3rd of every week going over the schedule and do nothing else.
Professor Bennett is a great guy and a really cool teacher.
Professor Bennett was a good teacher for Intro to Engineering, his class was really chill and he helped a lot when you needed it.

Professor Williams taught ENGR1620 for this first time and he did a pretty good job. His approach to intro to engineering is very different from the other professors. it may seem kinda boring, but the class is very laid back and the effort required is minimal. You learn Labview (data acquisition program), which was an interesting experience.

Bobby is the nicest man ever. Inside and outside of class he's so willing to help you and not just with class material. I once went to him with questions about another class I was struggling with and he talked to me for 45 minutes trying to help. Even if you don't like his subject, I really recommend taking a class just to have him as a professor.
Arbitrary grader who gives no feedback on assignments graded. Don't take ENGR 1620 with this man.

This class is a joke, I still don't get why we were required to take it, I got nothing out of it. Berger is a cool guy but I'm not sure he knows what hes supposed to lecture about. No text, if you do the final project you get an A, simple as that. Take his section and get an easy start to a not so easy E-school career

He seemed like a really cool guy, except he never prepared a lecture or taught us anything of use. I hoped to get a sense of what being an Engineer would be like and came out with nothing. He should be more aware of knowing when he has the class' attention.
Wonderful teacher, wonderful class section. Off-road baby strollers was a great project. He is enthusiastic, nice, and puts a ton of time and effort into the class.

He made some jokes in class, that were FUNNY, mostly because they were witty. He's a very chill person, and his class isn't hard. He requires you to go to class, but trust me its actually fun. Hes not very helpful when it comes to actually teaching some things, but you should be able to get an easy A. There some really fun group projects you do.

PLCP 1010.comment: What a fantastic class. David Waldner was very engaging, energetic, and passionate about his class. It was interesting and I would highly recommend it to anyone.

One of the most passionate and knowledgeable professors at the university. However, while the lectures were interesting and entertaining, most of them were very complex and hard to follow. Concepts overlapped each other and he would talk ramble on the entire time.
My favorite professor at UVA by FAR.
Prof Waldner, was a good professor, but lecture are insanely heavy and your exams, although they are open-notes are pretty difficult. There is also so much reading! Would probably not recommend.

Incredibly intelligent, funny professor. The class itself is fascinating & unlike most 101 level political science classes. There is a lot of reading, but you're not expected to read every word, just understand main takeaways and graphs. Attending lecture is incredibly important as any confusion about readings should be summarized there. Recommend!

Okay, yes, the readings are dense...but! Waldner provides guides on the important material and you don't need to closely read into everything. Waldner clearly knows what he is talking about and is always engaged. Waldner doesn't write purposefully tricky exams, though you do need to study! I enjoyed this class!

I really like Prof. Waldner! His lectures were informative and clear. My main gripe with this professor is how much reading we had to do, especially for a 1010 class. All the exams are essay-only too, so if you're not great with essays (like me), this might not be the class for you.

Waldner was a phenomenal professor. Before I signed up for the class I saw ratings that made me a bit nervous about how difficult he would be about grades, but I am so glad I took the class. I was never surprised by anything he put on a test, he would always make sure to review everything we needed to know at his review sessions before each exam.

This class is graded based on two midterms and a final, which are timed essay/short answer format. Professor Waldner was enthusiastic about the material, and the lectures were engaging. Attendance isn't mandatory, but it's hard to grasp the material if you don't go. Lots of readings each week, but I read about 60% and still succeeded.

The reading load for PLCP 1010 with Waldner was disproportionately heavy for an intro level class. I say this as someone with a high tolerance for homework. I did more reading for this class than I did for my 3000s level literature class, and it's all dry. Would not recommend.

Professor Waldner was amazing. Not only does he display a passion for the materials he teaches, but he also dedicates a large amount of his time and effort to his students. Without a doubt, you need to work a little harder in this class (reading), but Professor Waldner and the TAs are absolutely amazing and help you every step of the way.

This course has interesting lectures, but STATA can be tough to manage. STATA can be done collaboratively, but cannot give answers. TA's are great and cover all the lecture material. Find a partner/group to study with for the midterm and finals, which are essay based. Overall, Waldner is a great person and cares about his students. Take the class

Dr. Waldner was a great professor and lecturer. He was extremely knowledgable about the material and was obviously passionate about the subject. I found the lectures really interesting and did not miss any but the TA's cover the material fairly well in section so you may be able to get away with missing a few classes.

I have really enjoyed this class so far. For an intro-level class, Waldner is incredibly engaging and likes to focus on the nuances in state-building and political theories. I do not do any of the reading because my TA would summarize it all in discussion so I would just read her powerpoints before the exam. If you pay attention in class, it's easy

DO NOT TAKE A CLASS WITH THIS PROFESSOR! He is condescending, goes way too fast, and explains things terribly during lecture. The amount of reading he assigns is absurd and they are not even helpful. I wish I could go back in time and slap myself for signing up for this class.

Amazing professor, introductory classes could be tedious but he managed to make it funny and enjoyable. Lots of reading though, most of them are related to the topic yet not really fully discussed during the lecture. Some of his opinions could be quiet inspiring.

There were a ton of readings but the textbook wasn't often used or referenced. I enjoyed the topic so I found the lectures interesting. For people who hated Waldner, I would say they do not like a lot of work. Also, because it was an introductory course, many students showed no interest in participating rather than Waldner being boring.

Waldner is not funny or engaging. He is very arrogant and is not very adept at explaining things. He invents his own concepts and then does a poor job of teaching them. Lectures are painful to sit through. Avoid this class like the spanish influenza

A lot of reading but you can get away with not doing some of them. Waldner is funny and engaging, although he strikes some as arrogant. He is the stereotypical New Yorker. I liked his teaching style, although he did tend to make simple ideas more confusing than necessary. Not a terribly hard class. TAs do all the grading.

Interesting class and I learned a lot, but not what I expected. Way too much reading for a 1010 class. The material seems difficult, but it's really not that bad. Waldner is brilliant, but his teaching style was to explain simple ideas in a very complex way that made it difficult for me to learn. Must put in a lot of work to do well

Way too much reading for a 101 class. Arrogant professor who tries to make himself sound intelligent rather than simply explaining the material. Class is very disjointed and readings very loosely apply to lectures. Tries to be funnier than he is. AVOID THIS CLASS
Absolutely miserable. Don't take

Do not take this class if you are looking for an easy A or for a filler in your schedule or if you're a first year. Waldner was an awesome teacher but the material was very hard, the reading was very dense (and there was a lot of it), and he grades the class like a law school course (the final is 50% of your grade).
Interesting intro class, he is a very funny guy you can relate to.  Make sure to do the reading for the essay-style exam.

Currently in Comparative politics with Schoppa and I love it. I knew nothing about the subject when I started but I've learned a LOT. His lectures are interesting and very clear cut. Definitely attend class b/c his online notes are choppy. Don't buy w/the textbook, you'll never use it. DEFINITELY BY THE ARTICLE PACKET you'll need it for everything!

PLCP 2120.comment: Readings were long and difficult to comprehend. Tests were harshly graded and trying to do well was based on your TA helping to explain what you tried to read during the week. Teacher wasn't funny but thought he was and loved to stroke his ego.

Way too much reading for a 2000-level class. I liked him as a professor and he has a lot of really valuable things to say, but the reading load is RIDICULOUS. If you're passionate about the subject matter, you'll do fine. If you're considering the course for a requirement, I wouldn't recommend it.

he thinks he's really funny and he's usually not. lectures aren't mandatory because if you do the readings you can pass the exam, especially if you get in a study group. he posts the slides but they aren't helpful unless you took notes on what his blurbs of thoughts mean. exams are actually pretty easy; one all-encompassing question, most get Bs

Great class, great lecturer. Professor Fatton is Haitian born and can bring a personal perspective to global development and life under a dictatorship. He also brings intelligent academic study of the politics of development.
Professor is awesome and knows his stuff but sometimes his accent is incomprehensible. He needs to use a mic. 2 exams: 50-minutes. 1 10-pg paper. I learned a lot. Just focus on Easterly and Sachs.
really great lecturer. this class is very interesting, though it's at 9 AM.

Very interesting class. He's a great lecturer and it's easy to take notes on. There is a lot of reading but not all of it is necessary. I learned a lot but it's definitely not an easy A. You need to know what you're talking about for the exams and paper.

ENWR 2510.comment: This course is definitely as hard as you make it. Devin Donovan uses specifications grading instead of a "normal grading" system. I really feel that this helped me become less stressed over my writing and performance in this course. I highly recommend this course to fulfill your ENWR requirement, or to just take for fun!

Professor Donovan was a fantastic First Writing prof. Genuinely felt like he cared about every student in the class, and he was super receptive to whatever manner in which you wanted to approach an assignment. I took Contemplative Writing and would absolutely take his class again if I could. A fair amount of writing but it never felt like too much.

The class topic was Writing as Mindful Practice. It was a lot of BSing your way through the class at the beginning but less as it went on. Papers were interesting to write once you understood the prompt but fairly difficult to get to that point. If you're looking for an easy A for your First Writing Requirement, look elsewhere.

Dr. Carey is truly and undoubtedly one of the best professors I've ever had. She is attentive, intelligent, and overall deeply invested in what she teaches. So much so, it makes you deeply invested as well. I highly recommend any of her courses to anyone. Best decision I made was taking her class.

Dr. Carey truly cares about seeing her students improve, both as individuals and as writers. She is very attentive during class discussion and will challenge you to push yourself in your thinking. You will constantly be ready and writing for this class, but as long as you embrace the process, you will be successful.

ENWR 1510.comment: Prof. Donovan is one of the best professors I've had. He is very passionate about what he does and he is willing to go the extra mile to see you succeed. It's one few writing courses I've genuinely enjoyed. Our final project was to create a video out of something we enjoy doing (+ a few other things of course). It doesn't get better than that!

If you get the chance, Professor Donovan is definitely the best Professor to take an ENWR class with. Even for a student who isn't specifically passionate about writing, Professor Donovan's genuine passion and care for his students and sharing his love of writing makes this class extremely inspiring. An absolutely incredible Professor!

I really love Professor Donovan. He is so understanding and he will understand if you need an extra day or two to turn in your essays, just let him know beforehand. He doesn't grade harshly in my opinion, but even if he does, he allows you to rewrite essays to get a better grade and it does work. He's very caring a kind professor. Take his class.

Prof Donovan is great. He truly wants you to have a takeaway from his class and become a better writer- to which I did. The class can be tedious in the topics you talk about, but he is still worth taking. You don't exactly know your grade throughout the semester, just a general idea w certain feedback. It really depends on your final portfolio.

I cant say enough about how caring Donovan is. His transfer ENWR class was truly inspirational and helped me learn so much about myself despite me not taking the class seriously at first. Theres a strong focus on revision and growing as a learner and the class isnt difficult in the traditional sense because theres so much freedom in the assignments

His topics for his ENWRs are really applicable to every day life and writing - not super specific topics like some other ENWRs. Donovan really stresses discussion and making every student feel valued in class. Great guy who has a vision of how he wants his students to improve.

Prof. Donovan's class does provide inspirations for writing. However, if your intention of having a writing course is to fulfill requirement, I do not recommend you to take his course for the workload is heavy. Also, discussions are usually tedious and sometimes become arguments between two and three students.

Topic: The Art of Persuasion This class  will make you think. It isn't as easy as writing a boring and traditional English essay. He wants you to understand why you're arguing what you're arguing; why anyone should care.  Class discussions can be a bit hard to grasp, but they always tie back to how to authors can make an effective paper.
Professor Little is wonderful!! She wants to help students and is open to criticism about her teaching style.
my queen dana little: the easiest class you will ever take and the nicest woman you will ever meet

One of the kindest professors I have ever taken a class with. Anyone should do so if they are able, as I have learnt so much under her guidance. An absolute delight who is so passionate about her subject and always there for her students.
Marie was a very fair grader and was always willing to her students get better. She kept class as interesting as it could be for an ENWR

Laura is a great discussion leader.  Her comments on papers were very helpful and she is very smart (she was in the Jefferson Fellow).  I would recommend her to any student, especially if you love participating in discussions!
review must be at least 10 char
i liked him it was easy

The course content (topic: environmental writing) was pretty interesting and helped me with my writing. not too difficult but you still learn. Mason seems like a really considerate and insightful guy, always understanding and attentive to students needs. funny. I would definitely take his class again.
Prof. Casteen is an exceptional teacher who genuinely cares about his students. His class not only enhances writing skills but also imparts valuable life lessons.

The first day I didn't know what class this was. Afterwards, I loved it so much. I normally would never have taken a writing class like this, but Prof Casteen was very nice, funny, and thoughtful. You have few assignments but you have to be really careful. It's writing req so need to go to class, but overall he's one of the greatest prof. ever.

Her ENWR on Writing about Television was so fun and a really great way to teach writing. She is extremely caring for all of her students and if you have completed a certain threshold of assignments by the end of the semester, you get an A. If this class is offered, TAKE IT!
Really great teacher and fun class!

Cristina is an amazing professor who gives every student the chance to succeed and works to make sure that all students achieve their goal. Cristina hypes up students when you do things well and is very communicative and easy to talk to. She makes every student feel important and like they belong in her class and she is very funny.

Prof. Dillon-English was a phenomenal teacher. Very lenient grader. Not many papers to write. Two long papers (about 4-5 pages each, one near the middle of the semester, one as the final). Participation counts, especially since it's a small class, but he creates such a warm environment to the point where you feel connected to him and your peers.

TAKE THIS CLASS!! Jeddie is the best. This was such a fun and interesting class. You are given a lot of creative freedom and Jeddie is a very generous grader. The assignments are fun and not hard at all. The homework takes barely any time, and if you follow all the guidelines and participate in class, you should get an A.

I loved this class, and I usually hate English. Jeddie is approachable, knowledgeable, and he knows a lot about writing. I considered myself an elite writer going into college, but he showed me there was so much more to learn.

I LOVED this class! I never felt bored during class and was always engaged. Jeddie is such a cool, understanding and amazing professor. He made the class fun and interesting. The course materials were not heavy and very doable. The three writing projects were also very fun and interesting to write.
Great professor

Jeddie cares a lot about his students and his class quite a bit. You can see just how much he cares by the effort he puts into making the class engaging through lectures and assignments. I would highly recommend taking the class!

Absolutely adored his class! One of my favorite classes for the fall semester even though it was an ENWR class. The topics we discussed were extremely interesting, engaging, and thought-provoking and he is a very thoughtful and caring professor. Highly recommend!

Professor Sophronius is amazing, he really cares about his students and always made sure that we were doing okay, mentally and academically. He always provided us with extra office hours if needed, support, and even gave us a potluck for our last day of class. He is extremely helpful if you are not comfortable with writing he is always helpful.

Professor Sophronius' class was easily one of my most favorite classes of all time. He makes each lecture interesting and engaging for students of all backgrounds and interests. Homework can be lengthy at times, but yet still very engaging. Prof. Sophronius was always readily available through email and in-person for feedback or to chat. 10/10

ENWR 2520.comment: He's a decent instructor. Could be worse. On the other hand, could be much better. Lectures are painfully boring at times. He's not very good at posting assignments at least three assignments were posted very late the night before they were due. Overall, I would stay away from him unless you really need a writing requirement.
Driver is extremely biased and pretty grumpy. If you want to take his laziness course, prepared for him to try to convey you that it is good to be lazy. Pretty boering class.
Professor Driver was wonderful. He's entertaining and very helpful with learning new writing skills. I always looked forward to his classes!

Very nice guy -- a good person to get to know. I was a fan of his ENWR 1510 Course, "Writing About Food". I felt that some of the readings were a bit boring, but he taught me a lot and is a great person. Happy I took my ENWR with Keith Driver
Amazing class taught by an even more amazing professor. 10/10 would recommend. Work's not horrible -- gets rid of second writing in an interesting and fun way.

ENWR 2259.comment: Professor Donovan was awesome! He was very flexible and accommodating to what the class' needs were, and he was totally open to new ideas. He was very invested in us and wanted everyone to do well, and loved hearing about people's opinions. He was always prepared with new, interesting readers and is a great at paper feedback. Would recommend!

MDST 3050.comment: Takes an unfathomably long amount of time to grade assignments and gives no feedback. Syllabus is also contradictory and percentages add up to over 100%. This class is just not it.

He's a super passionate and is extremely knowledgeable in the course material. He takes attendance every day so you can't really afford more than 2 skips. He gives lot of group work and group projects which can be annoying in the media studies curriculum. Good professor, bad class.
I've taken 2 classes with her and she is notably kind and supportive. She allows extensions when students need and very good at emailing and response times. Would recommend to anyone!
Amazing lecturer! Honestly one of the most engaging Ive had at UVA!
Keara is a fantastic lecturer!! She does a great job of making them engaging and actually interesting. Shes also a fair grader and as long you do the readings, you should be fine.

Such an unnecessarily tough grader. If your social beliefs don't 100% align with hers, don't expect a good grade on anything. Doesn't make her expectations completely clear, and grades as if you're in a grad school level course. Don't take her class unless you're able to completely dedicate your time to it.

Just a dreadful course. If you were to suck all the enthusiasm and joy out of the study of media, you would be left with this. The course is so "by the book" that it hurts. If I wanted to learn in such a manner, I would read a dictionary. No spirit, just an absurd number of pages shoved in your face with a bill at the end of the semester. Terrible.

Spend as much time as possible on papers, because it is a grade that you have more control over. The midterm and final are graded very harshly.  She will state not to cite from the text too much, but she really wants you too. Lectures are boring!

RELG 2160.comment: I took this class for an easy credit 2nd-semester 1st year. While the class material as a whole was fairly easy, and Heather Warren's lectures were interesting, the TA graded exams somewhat harshly, and it wasn't the "easy A" type of class that I was expecting. Prof Warren also requires students to handwrite notes fervently while she lectures.

Gives a study before exams, and then all exam material is pulled from the study guide. Exams are handwritten in blue books, and have vocab/quotes/essay sections. Decent bit of writing but easy to study for. Go to lecture though and take good notes! That's where you get info for study guide. I didn't read much, but readings obviously help.

RELG 1010.comment: test questions were pulled directly from study guide-completely possible to get a perfect 100 in the class if you are good at memorization. Going to lecture and taking notes is definitely helpful, but u could probably skip every lecture and cram for exams and still do well. Warren is funny and endearing, really cares about her students, love her.

Didn't go to lecture other than to take tests, you don't really need to. Attendance at the discussion section is mandatory, though. She gives a study guide before tests and most answers are on Quizlet or you'll go over them in your discussion section. Easy grade with little effort compared to other courses.

As long as you study, you will get an A in this class. Gives a "study guide" ahead of time and pulls all exam questions from the study guide. If you have any questions and ask her through email, she will usually respond immediately with great amount of detail.

Professor Warren's class isn't too difficult as long as you do the work. All exam material is on a study guide given about a week and a half ahead of time and she is responsive to questions. Exams are entirely written (with IDs, quote IDs, and an essay) and are very memorization heavy - do not put studying off. Solid choice for gen ed.

Heather Warren is a great professor. I have taken her for 3 classes at UVA and she sets very clear expectations, and prepares you well for the tests which are not too difficult. Go to lecture, use her study guides and you'll be set!

Professor Warren is an amazing lecturer: there is so much substance in her lectures (which sometimes makes it hard to keep up but if you collaborate on notes and study in groups, you'll be fine) and I learned so much every class. Amazing class for a Religion major: she packs so much clear, relevant information into this course. She's very cool.

Clearly the best class of my first semester.  Heather Warren is an amazing professor!  Lectures cover a lot of material each day, so be prepared to write. (no computers allowed)  I only read the primary sources, not the extra textbook readings, and did fine.  Make sure to ask questions to your TA about the study guide-- they are very helpful.

CHEM 1410.comment: I. Love. Welch. What a great guy. Lecture's aren't the most helpful but if you go to his office hours he will explain something over and over until you get it. Also the grade weighting of the course made it not that bad too. Chem is still hard but definitely doable with him and effort put in outside of class. I definitely recommend for chem 1
he is my dad
He is a great professor, very clear and is always available for questions and help.

Welch did a great job at explaining the topics from the textbook in lectures and made it very worthwhile to attend class. The lectures are also all recorded and the grading in the class is very fair, where partial credit is given fairly often on the exams for missed answers
His Lectures were great, he made complex topics easy to understand. He is lenient and understanding concerning work and deadlines.
super helpful at office hours, great lecturer, and really nice guy. overall, he slays

Professor Welch was a very kind and interesting professor. The way he structured class really helps the way you learn the material. he was very approachable if you have any questions. I would definitely choose him over the other professors! Highly Recommend!!!

Welch is by far the best lecturer to have for chem 1410. The content is the same as all of the other professors, but his way of speaking and use of examples makes the class actually interesting, and a hard one to fall asleep in. Beyond being a great prof, hes also an incredibly nice person. 10/10 would take him if possible.

Avoid this class if you can. Welch seems like a nice, cool guy but he holds only 2.5 office hours per week which are usually completely full and his TAs don't hold any office hours. His lectures cover only the most basic material of the course, but the tests are extremely hard in comparison. It's very difficult to get any help in this class.

I took this class online due to COVID-19 so the format of the class was different than most years. Professor Welch was always amazing at explaining concepts and was very open to questions. The tests were slightly difficult and require a reasonable amount of studying but it is reasonable. I definitely think he is the best chemistry professor here.

Welch is pretty chill. His lectures are a little scattered or off topic on occasion, but the readings are really good and on topic for the exam. This class is a lot of work but also if you pay attention and don't get behind you can get a good grade pretty easily. If you're going to take intro chem, take it with Welch.

Show up to class and pay attention to his lecture. You don't have to read the textbook. Welch is nice and a lot of people think that he's super chill. Not an easy A but not hard overall. Definitely one of the better intro Chem professor at UVa. There is usually a waitlist to get into his class but don't panic most people will eventually get in.

Straightforward class. Test questions are like the homework questions, so do the weekly homework and make sure you understand it and you'll be fine. I definitely recommend reading the chapters to fully understand what's going on -- chem isn't easy, but Welch is chill and doesn't try to trip you up. Put in the effort and you should succeed.
I love this man. He genuinely cares about his students and does his best to make sure everyone understands the material. Also adds some humor into his lectures which makes the class more enjoyable.

Good teacher take it with him. He gave out a lot of extra point in 1410. Test are fair but he do occasionally throw in about 3 tricky question each exam.  Your lowest exam score is only worth 6 percent. I mad because he didnt round my 92.8 to a A because the class average was a 85 percent.

Welch is a great professor. It is important to do the readings before lecture, otherwise lecture doesn't make sense and you're lost. He's very helpful in office hours. He didn't have practice tests this semester, which would've been nice, but moving forward he may. He made chemistry seem light, because of his humor. But chemistry is still hard.

Welch is an excellent lecturer and won't put you to sleep. Power points and written out problem answers from class are always posted online. He has clicker questions in class (not graded by accuracy) that go toward a participation grade. Weekly problem sets are not as difficult as those used by the other chem professors.
