This professor is among the best I've had at U Va. Please keep her! She really cares about the students and gives one of the most brilliantly organized courses I've had, teaching really important material to a wide range of students.

ASTR 4810.comment: I took his class last semester and he was a great professor. The lectures were helpful and interesting, the group work in class was useful for understanding, and he was very available during office hours.

ASTR 1250.comment: absolutely terrible. asks questions on hw that he doesnt cover in lecture. learning catalytics in-class questions do not go through majority of the time so you lose points. no idea what hes saying 100% of the time. if youre not an astronomy major dont take alien worlds. if you dont put your hw answers in his exact wordsf.

ASTR 3420.comment: Lectures could get long and boring at times, however the subject was super interesting and you could tell he really cared about it. The tests were very straightforward - all multiple choice.

Class was easy in a way (no outside work, but exams could be very nit-picky), but painfully boring. Phil seems like a good guy, and sometimes the powerpoints were funny, but his delivery was very flat and NO ONE paid attention. Subject matter in theory was really interesting at times, though.
Great teacher, fun and interesting subject, clear, relatively easy

COMM 3230.comment: Professor Martin is THE BEST! He truly cares about his students and really feels invested in all of our futures. He is a truly special professor.

Professor Martin is awesome! He really cares about his students and is so knowledgable about consulting and other business fields. He is a very fascinating lecturer and always brings in great guest speakers.

ENTP 1010.comment:
What you will gain from this class: 
1) Business Mindset (how to become an entrepreneur in action)
2) Business Notions (a lot of useful tools such as business model canvas, value propositions, etc.)
3) Connections and Experience (they invite many guest speakers)

What you won't learn from this class:
1) How to start a company
2) Legal Issues

KINE 3450.comment: Prof knows his stuff. Cites papers at will and frequently goes "off reading" in response to student queries to show studies that address the questions even if not part of the readings. Exams are straightforward if you come to class. Has a very direct sense of humor.

ENSP 3559.comment: Passionate and intelligent.  He's obviously an ex(?)-hippie and tends to let students' faulty arguments slide, but his are always well thought out and usually brilliant.  If you get the chance, talk Freud with him because his thoughts on the good doctor are always illuminating.

I took her J-Term class, and even though I heard that taking a two week class can be very strenuous, she made it a very enjoyable experience.  She was very kind and at the same time, did a great job of critiquing me without being offensive in any way.  I would take another class with her any day.  She is by far one of UVa's greatest professors.

ENLT 2555.comment: He is a good teacher, but there are times when he goes on 15 minute rambles.

Professor Casteen is one of the few professors who actually cares that we learn instead of just memorize information. He is always prepared for class and he brings books/magazines to relate to the topic of the lecture which really helps with connecting themes. His early bird specials are something to treasure, & he gives solid life advice too.

Jost is a very tough cookies. He makes you work for your grades. His lectures are very boring and sometimes unclear. participating in class is huge; for it causes him to favor you at times. He is a cool guy, but can be very arrogant and stubborn at times.

I thought Jost was a good choice at first. He seemed interested in me and helping me to excel in the class. After a while I realized he just loves to hear himself talk. He tends to reject any ideas that students may have unless they are very similar to his. Nice guy, but mediocre lecturer. If you write well, you'll be ok.

I have no problem with teachers who make you argue your point if it goes against their own. However, he just flat out rejects any ideas that do not go along with his own without even allowing you to explain it. Normally, I enjoy discussion style classes and contributing to them but I think I will keep my mouth shut from now on.
His lectures tend to drone on and on. If you're an English major, he'll be easier for you. If you have no clue what you're doing, take another professor.
Great professor who really knows his stuff, but he can be a bit hard to understand if you are not an English major. He will work with you if you want to do well in his class.
Prof. Chakravorty is incredible. Her class is challenging and engaging, and she really pushes you to look beyond the obvious when crafting an argument. I highly recommend any class she teaches.

Professor Wall is a very sweet woman who is really passionate about literature. She leads great discussions every class. There was only a one page commentary due once a week and three papers which she gives you very personal feedback about. She is the kindest woman who knows what she's talking about and is happy to share her time with anyone.
Brad has been one of my favorite professors so far! Super enthusiastic, very witty, and genuinely interested in what everyone has to say! You will not regret taking a class with him, he's awesome!
Brad is the man. He is the best essay grader at UVA.

She is awesome! Very down to earth. She swears in class and wants student involvement. I took her literature class so you had to read to contribute to class. She is SO helpful and easy to talk to. She even lets you turn in papers late if you let her know 72 hours in advance.

Cara's class was one of the most insightful and interesting classes I've taken at UVA, and she's just a grad student! The reading list is fantastically interesting; it's a lot of stuff you've always wanted to read in an academic setting but never have (like Sherlock Holmes, for example). Highly recommended.

Cara is an amazing! She's an extremely knowledgeable teacher--it's clear that she really spends time building a syllabus and really cares about her students' progress and really loves english and teaching. Really great reading list and always extremely engaging

Great teacher, excellent constructive criticism for papers. This man will open your mind and change the way you think. And while his feedback on papers is impessive, it takes a long time for the papers to come back.
He's incredibly nice. And incredibly attractive.
i loved this class. best english class i've ever taken.

Take his class! Prof. McDermott is the professor who truly cares about what you have to say and improving your writing - he let me rewrite both of my papers because he was actually interested in seeing what I had to say and my writing skills. Invited the entire class over for dinner and made Middle English Literature incredibly interesting and fun!

CHEM 1810.comment: I loved Harman. I had him for 1810 and it was the best chemistry class I've ever taken. The content was difficult and some of it he didn't have time to cover in class, so we had to do it outside of class. Other than that, there was no homework outside of class. The class is heavily curved, I ended with around a 70 on all exams and ended with an A!
Professor Harman's chemistry class is challenging but rewarding. His infectious enthusiasm makes the lectures lively and engaging, even at 8am. Attend class, use Unstuckstudy, and you'll excel.

My favorite class I've ever taken. Material is very tough but Harman provides plenty of resources and generous ways to get points back on tests with corrections for 1/2 points back. Office hours are very useful and accessible (save time right after lecture to go).

Beware of lab 1811!! It is very difficult and tedious, take 1411 lab w/ 1810 lecture

Amazing class. I have no interest in majoring in chem (am premed) but this has me leaning heavily toward a minor or taking more intricate classes. As an engineering major, I am also very happy i decided for the 1411 lab with this, I've heard brutal things.

Harman has influenced me to a degree where I aspire to be as excited to talk about a topic as he talks about chemistry. He speaks with such enthusiasm for the topic and inspired me to major in chemistry. If you are invested in chemistry and want to have a great time learning it with an easy-to-approach and reasonable professor, take his classes.

Chemistry at 8am might not be the preferred, prof. Harman is so passionate about chemistry. Although you might be very interested in chemistry, beware, it is an extremely difficult class for those with an advanced chemistry background (ap chem or the equivalent). So if you don't have that chemistry background, you're up for a challenge.

Professor Harman is the most gifted instructor I have met through all of my years in school. While the course content is admittedly extraordinarily difficult, his incredible teaching ability makes the class worth its rigor. He truly cares about his students and has a genuine love for teaching.

Professor Harman is just awesome! He is freakishly knowledgable and a very gifted lecturer; the fact that I was fully awake and tuned in during the 8am lectures speaks volumes. His tests are very difficult and they get progressively harder, so maximize points on the first two exams because the final will be brutal. Curves are generous, though!

I strongly recommend this for Engineering students who only need 1 semester of chemistry. 1810 was awesome, but I really would not want to take 1820 next semester. You will love Dean Harman and honestly it's hard not to get a B+ to an A in this class if you try. BEWARE of 1811 (Lab section). If you're in engineering take 1810 with 1411 lab.
Great professor who is passionate and wants to help you! Lectures are fairly interesting too for 8 ams! Key to doing well in this class is attending lectures AND consistently going to office hours.

Professor Harman is a great teacher, but the style may not be for everyone. Lectures are fascinating, but tend to be about the theory behind something rather than how to use it on an exam. You only go over how to do the questions as homework/with TAs in discussion, unless you go to office hours. However, if you work/study hard, you'll be rewarded.

Harman is a god among men.1810 is a very difficult class but the material is fascinating and Harman shows he cares about his students. 3 tests at 25% each, but you get half points back for corrections and he curves the grades at the end. Definitely one of the best professors I've had so far, and NO you don't need to take AP Chem to take this class.

Prof Harman is hands down the nicest professor you'll have in college; he takes time to teach you, whether individually or in a group. If you did really well in AP or IB Chem, then this class isn't a bad idea. It's fast paced, but TAs or the professor will help you. Warning: test average 60-70%, but he offers corrections for half credit back.
Absolutely phenomenal, do not be scared to take this class, you will get a B+ if you just try. But if you care about GPA, beware of 1811 lab and Professor Sen Zhang

NOTE FOR INCOMING FIRST YEARS
This post is NOT for Professor Harman (he is good), rather I want to warn you before entering the course. Please check out the 1/5 rating for Professor Serbulea for additional information (I am on a character limit here).You should not take the 1800 sequence. The 1800 sequence community is very snobbish and elite. ...

You could never miss a day of Harman's lectures or you would be so hopelessly lost. However, if you put in the work, take notes, rewrite the notes like he says, you will be fine. Going to the discussion groups was helpful because a lot of what was there was also on the test in some way or another. I was a hard class. if you work you will be ok

Harman is great! Class is hard and you better work hard, but if you're at all interested in chemistry, I highly recommend. He also curves the grades at the end, so it's not *that* bad at the end of the day.
Online 1810 was still a great class! Professor Harman is super knowledgeable and his office hours were very very helpful. Difficult tests but prepares you well for future chem classes.

Professor Harman's class is largely graded on effort. Homework and test corrections are graded on completion which gives you an advantage in grading. However, his lectures and presentation of information are disorganized. I had credit for gen chem and took this as a refresher and I do not think it really prepares you for organic chemistry.

Professor Harman is a fantastic person and teacher! Chem 1810 was as engaging as it could be online, and Harman worked hard to make it fun for first-years this fall. The class is not a walk in the park, but Harman is there to help out and you get corrections on the exams which is a lifesaver. 1230982/10 would recommend!

Harman is amazing. Lectures were tough at 8 am, but always engaging and he cares so much about each student. Office hours are great. Exams are VERY challenging, but usually, a 65% will be an A/A- due to corrections/curve. This proves that he really wants students to attempt to apply what they learned on the exams. Work hard, you'll get an A.

Honestly, such a genuinely nice guy. His class is very difficult, but he is so caring about his students and his office hours are incredibly helpful. The tests are like nothing you've ever seen but he does allow for test corrections, so if you go to lectures and ask for help you'll probably do fine. Taking his class is definitely worth taking 1810.
Greatest chem prof I've had here. HIs office hours were like a second lecture

Harman is a fantastic teacher, especially since he rarely teaches other classes besides advanced intro chem, but this class is hard unless you want to major in chem. It's doable, but not for the lazy or faint of heart.

Harman is awesome! This class is not easy, and the tests definitely require studying, but you will come out of this with the best chemistry understanding in the world. He is such a clear lecturer and is totally invested in making sure everybody understands the concepts. He sends out plenty of practice tests and review sheets to help. Great class!

Professor Harman really does care about students, but you still need to work hard in the class. The best thing you can do for yourself is to ask questions and attend office hours if you are stuck. It is not an easy course, but If you put effort in, you will attain great results.

This was the greatest class I have taken just because of the professor. It was definitely a tough class, but no problem with dedication. If you are choosing between the 800 series or the 400 series for chemistry, this class is a must, even if you choose to drop to the 400 series afterwards. Take this professor's class. You won't get another chance.
The class is hard, but the professor explains everything very clearly. He has made Chemistry fun. Definitely should take the class.

This class is VERY difficult. It is fast paced and the first month consists of learning that everything you ever knew about Chemistry was a lie; however, Harman is an amazing professor. He makes himself available and explains things as clearly as possible. This class was definitely worth it.
This class is by no means easy, but Harman is one of the best teachers out there. He has a deep understanding of the topic and his passion for it makes the class so much more interesting.

CHEM 1800.comment: Very difficult with only 3 exams, but he does offer test corrections.

Prof. Harman is awesome. He devotes half of his lecture days to teaching & helping students afterwards. Expert in his field, really smart guy. Has high expectations, evidenced by the exam. The course is as challenging as it's said to be but also very rewarding. If you don't understand something (sometimes everything) it's your job to ASK QUESTIONS.

Harman genuinely cares about every student doing well in the class. His lectures are so clear that you never have to read the textbook. I took good notes during lectures, went to office hours, and ended up with an A.

CHM 1810.comment: He's an excellent teacher. He's clear and is very willing to help you with anything you're struggling with. However, the class is really difficult. Although he's great, I would still recommend getting supplementary help. I used clutch prep and ended up with an A. But I really had to be dedicated.

USEM 1570.comment: "Systems Thinking and Sustainability" was an amazing USEM. Mark White was the most engaging professor I've had at UVA thus far.
he never actually answers any questions.. he just says "yes good question, what do you think?"
This class is very simple if you do the readings and Rick only lectures for an hour instead of the full class time.
Rick is the man. Just write a little bit and talk. The class is engaging and interesting. He is a kind old man with a big heart.

At first, classes would be really interesting group discussions about death. As the semester went on, it kind of became more of a lecture with very little participation. You could probably get away with skimming readings. Papers were graded in a super annoying way, but were easy to get an A on.

He is a fantastic teacher. Gives great insight to the course and is clearly very intelligent. also funny and sweet in an old man kind of way. 3 papers (pretty short/broad topics) and participation are the only parts of your grade. He is awesome and so is the class. Easy 2 credits!!

I love this professor! Class readings are completely optional. As a professor, he tends to have very long lectures instead of discussions but he obviously very much cares about what he is teaching! You won't get a good grade on the exam but everyone comes out of the course with an A. He is one of those professors who doesn't care about grades.

Fascinating man and interesting class.  His lectures can get somewhat rambling and dull at points but he really is a fascinating man to listen to, especially near the end of the course when he teaches about the fall of the USSR by telling stories about his time growing up and living there.  Lots of outside reading that is kinda dull

Super cool person but her class is boring, can't really place why but it's just not as engaging as you would expect for a class about "Trauma, Accountability, Healing." The readings were the most interesting part of this class but it's kind of lot (luckily you can get away without reading all of it super thoroughly).

Laughon is pretty cool but her class "Gender Violence and Culture" was one of the most depressing and boring things I've ever experienced. Attendance is a huge part of your grade. Spare yourself, don't take this class.
Kathryn is great! Her USEM "Gender, Violence, and Culture" is a great class and a pretty easy A. Took this my first semester and loved it.

Took "Great Historical Speeches" with Prof Patterson. The course was very interesting and Patterson was a great professor. He's very straightforward and relaxed, which made class enjoyable and spontaneous. Take a course with him if you can!
Extremely nice teacher. Very easy. The material was pretty interesting.  Basically, you meet once a week and make a video and blog. Thumbs up!

Ecoacoustics was a really awesome class. You have to approach it with an open mind and you are exposed to some really interesting music. Professor Burtner is an expert and he's definitely passionate about the subject. Not the hardest class you'll take, but highly recommended.

STAT 6021.comment: Boring and unresponsive lecturer. Found my high school AP stats was taught better than Jeffrey's STAT 3XXX.

Honestly one of the best professors in terms of pedagogical techniques. Every single module by outlined by objectives so you know what to do since he's so organized with his structure for the class. Accessible without making you feel suffocated but you know he gives plenty of effort and care into the class and wants his students to succeed!

STAT 4630.comment: Best professor even had. The course itself is very hard. But the professor made it really easy to follow along. He writes all the slides, R codes, labs, solutions, solutions in R codes, and organize them so nicely that you can just follow along. Unlike other professors, he puts most of the work/burden on himself and demands little on students.

ECE 2330.comment: In Digital Logic Design, we designed every component of a simple cpu in VHDL. As a first-year, I learned what hardware engineers actually do in this class. Prof DeLong is very lenient and you will absolutely get an A if you do the work, get help when necessary, turn everything in on time, and try. Strongly recommend.

Easily one of the best professors at UVA. She explains everything clearly and I don't know how she does is but she just knows it when you're confused and then she'd immediately address the confusion. Her lectures are seamlessly connected, so don't skip any and be sure to watch the recording if you absolutely have to, or you will be confounded.

He's a brilliant man, but unfortunately not a great lecturer. He just kind of speeds through concepts as he writes them, and expects you to understand them after the first go around. He had a  huge curve on the final, which I'm pretty sure is the only way I got an A, because I know i bombed it. Be prepared to put in long hours teaching yourself

CS 3120.comment: Good, charismatic lecturer! Everything is quite straightforward in the class, but the material itself is inherently difficult. Lecture is good, but I would say the textbook carried me in this class. One thing I wasn't a fan of was that the exam grades made up the majority of our grade and the grading on those tests was a bit harsh.

Floryan is legendary, actually one of the coolest and most laid back CS professors at UVA. He is full of humor and is happy to make the class burst out into laughter on many occasions. He is also happy to adjust the course based on how the semester is going (due dates were extended when a lot of people were lagging behind).

Professor Evans was definitely my favorite professor this semester. It's very clear that he puts in the time to make lectures interesting and I found myself excited to come to every lecture, which is surprising and impressive given the content of the course. Definitely recommend taking a class from him at some point. Was accessible outside of class

CS 4102.comment: I would not have taken this class if it wasn't with Floryan. Great professor. That being said, his classes are super difficult. Be prepared to work forever on Algo homework and still not feel prepared for the exams. It's a tough class, he makes it tough, but he's such a great lecturer and you do really learn in classes he teaches.
Floryan was the best professor I've had at UVA.  He is the most clear and organized teacher I've had, and he's really good at helping students get through tough patches in the semester.
Nathan Brunelle is an angel sent from heaven to teach algorithms
Great professor, very clear. Wants you to learn. Not always the most organized, very helpful.

If you define a smart person as someone that goes through material really fast and leaves out many small details in explaining complex subjects than this guy is really smart, you can't take that away from someone that has degrees from Harvard and MIT.  I would only recommend taking his classes for students that have strong fundamentals in subject

This class required A LOT of work, but if you have the time to go to multiple office hours and have a study group you can do the homeworks with, you can do well. Unless you are especially good at algorithms, I would recommend that you take this class ONLY if you are able to go to a majority of the office hours and have a group to work with.

My first time failing a class. If you don't like working with others then you need to be pretty genius at this stuff to get by. Weekly, four-question homeworks that take hours, even if you're working with a group. To his credit, he tries to make it clear, but the material is absolutely nightmarish. Hint: know your logs and run-times going in.

Algorithm was the hardest and yet most interesting class I have ever taken at UVA. The problem sets were challenging and took forever to think up solutions and even more time to type it up in LaTeX. However, I learned a great deal about the subject matter. Definitely recommend for those  who want to challenge themselves and learn about algorithm.

Don't know what these ppl are talkin about.  By far the best class in terms of what I've gotten in return: real-life problem solving skills. Shelat is hard, rigorous, and really pushes his students, but if you make an effort to learn the material, he'll ace you.  Truly cares about his students.

CS 3205.comment: Floryan is awesome!! I've taken Algorithms and HCI and I have enjoyed both of them. He really wants to teach the students and is really understanding of what the students need! For HCI, he even extended the deadline of a homework assignment and push backed a test to make it easier on us.

Floryan is a good lecturer and the material is interesting but... The assignments' instructions are unclear, and the one programming homework given was absurd and more about nonsensical implementations in Java than it is about HCI. Grading is often very subjective and harsh. You'll get random points deducted for formatting. Poorly organized class.
Great lectures Open note quizzes project is important Thursday lectures are fun

HCI with this professor is, in a word, painful. Firstly, if you've ever had issues with group work, don't even consider taking this course as it's 90% groupwork. He always tries to fit far more than he can teach in his lectures, but still quizzes us on what he had to skip over because of time. Overall, a poor teacher of what was once a good class.

CS 3710.comment: Super down to earth professor who always makes sure to get to know students and always shared funny/interesting personal stories. Very understanding of students' workloads. Thought it was amazing how in touch the professor was with their word choices to make sure all students were respected and through providing insight into the professional world.
I knew nothing about security and I learned a ton. Labs are really well done. Best final exam ever!

This was by far my favorite class so far. I actually learned things that I put on my resume and talked about in interviews. Professor Orebaugh is was always available to help me with the labs and provide career advice. She brings such a great energy to the lectures and I love hearing her stories about all of the things she has done in industry.

CS 4457.comment: Learned a lot about computer networks. I was surprised and impressed by the hands on labs. I wasn't expecting to learn real world skills, but I really enjoyed it. I also really like the course long network design project. I was able to put what I learned to use.

SEC 3010.comment: I would also say the professor is Respected, Gives good feedback, has amazing lectures, and so on. It is truly a privilege to take this class with the professor as the labs are fun and applicable to the real world. Being limited in what I can put here I would say a lot more good about the professor, but overall I would say take her classes.

ISSS 3401.comment: I loved the Smart Cities Enabling Sustainability course. I took it because I had previously taken Principles of Sustainability with Dr. Orebaugh and LOVED IT. She is very inspirational about the topic of sustainability. Everything she teaches in class can be related to the individual or where the individual lives.

I changed my career because of this class! I was kind of interested in sustainability, but I had no idea the impact I could have. Dr. Orebaugh is so inspirational and shows us all that we can make a difference in our own cities. Smart Cities Enabling Sustainability is a must take elective! I just wish BIS had a sustainability concentration.

BUS 5120.comment: I took BUS 5120 Securing the Internet of Things as an elective. I wasn't sure what to expect, but I loved this course! Dr. Orebaugh gives great lectures and didn't make the material too complicated for me to understand (like others often do!). I learned impacts, attacks, and mitigations for the IoT and cyber physical systems. Great class!

BUS 5030.comment: We had a course long project where the class performed like a consulting firm to create a security architecture for each of our "clients". I've never had a class like this and it was really creative and helpful to prepare me for a job in security consulting. The professor guided us through every step and provided a lot of support along the way.

CHEM 4320.comment: Inorganic chemistry is insanely difficult for anybody to fathom—like orgo on 2x speed. While flipped classrooms in early covid took some getting used to, Prof Machan was always running up and down the lecture hall stairs to answer any and every question you had. So many (un-graded) practice problems, and they're exactly like the test. TY Sir.
Useless lectures and useless office hours made for an incredibly enlightening semester with good ol Charlie :):):):)

Prof Machan was so fun. He did a lot of crazy in class demonstrations and had funny extra credit questions. Test review days are hawaiin shirt days and if you show up wearing one you get candy. some of the stuff on the test won't be in the review slides, so make sure to study the review slides , practice tests, & TA review

Prof. Fraser is a very nice and pleasant person to talk to. However, her Inorganic Chemistry class is very difficult - mostly due to a serious lack of organization and a big difficulty gap between what's taught in class and what's asked on tests. Teaches basic concepts only to test you on details and extreme cases.

AAS 3500.comment: Dr. Richardson (formerly of UNC) was one of the most passionate professors whom I have ever met. Her syllabus was stacked with a perfect balance between journal articles that show the problems that persist in medicine and stories to show you why you should care. As a current med student, I firmly believe her class should be a pre-med requirement.

LPPP 2200.comment: Johannessen lectures in a very straight-forward way. Readings are so optional I did none of them. Getting a good TA matters for writing your memo. Prof is very kind and knowledgeable. Class can be a bit dry sometimes but not hard to get the A if you put in the work. All tests are open-note.

LPPP 3200.comment: I took Professor Johannessen's Intro to Public Policy in Fall 2020 and he was compassionate and flexible, especially during COVID. His lectures were engaging and all of the important terminology was color-coded so note-taking was easy. The workload was somewhat heavy, but nothing out of line with similar classes at UVA.
Really nice and caring prof, especially during COVID. Very clear expectations with clear lectures with lots of examples. Definitely worth taking.

SOC 3480.comment: The lectures are incredibly boring and the readings are very dry. The tests are rather easy, he gives the prompt the class before and you can bring a sheet of notes to write the essay on the prompt the day of. I wouldn't take this class again but I did learn some interesting things.

SOC 3310.comment: I only took this class because the course description made it seem really interesting. It's basically a philosophy class though and he's a terrible teacher. Not engaging at all. Powerpoints are black text on a white background. People sign into attendance and ultimately get up and leave during the class. No tests-just papers,but he's a picky grader

Goofy and quirky, but grades based on engagement with the material and original thoughts, not necessarily accuracy. Probably wouldn't take the class again, but I did learn some interesting things in this class.

He wants you to quote his slides verbatim or else he will dock your points like crazy even if your answer is right. If you are sick and miss class, good luck because you are not getting any notes. He is unreasonable, gives a million writing assignments and incredibly boring. Take another prof.

Prof Skubby is the best - he's inspirational, kind, and accommodating. If you have lots of work for other classes, he will let you turn in assignments late. Class consists of reading summaries every few weeks, midterm/final, and a term paper. Daily class isn't challenging and is very interesting. Take this class if you're looking for an easy one.

SOC 2900.comment: This class is one of the most boring, useless classes I've ever take. The professor attempts to make this 2000 level class harder than it needs to be by making four assignments each week that don't actually help you learn the material, but is judged solely on whether you can schedule to do them. He has an accent and rambles quickly through lecture.

SOC 2559.comment: This class was just okay.  I pretty much hated it at the beginning because the lecture style was unorganized and the slides were bad, but things got much, much better after the midterm.  He's a really nice guy and does want you to do well, but it's not a class I would go out of my way to recommend to anyone.

I took Economy and Society with him and it was an interesting class.He's not the most exciting lecturer especially that early in the morning, but lectures were very clear and organized and really helped with understanding the readings.Midterm was pretty easy,straight from the slides,and weekly exercises weren't too bad.Overall,I'm glad I took it.

Tara really is very passionate about the subject matter, and she really tries to make the class feel the same about it. For a 200 level class there is a lot of reading, but if you do the reading and go to lectures/discussion the class is very manageable.

I hated this class. I felt that she was very biased and grades for students who didn't agree with her perspective were lower. Although Tara herself was nice, the reading material was accusatory, angry, and single-sided. Don't take this class if you are conservative at all. The tests are also tricky with the wording.

tara's really nice. the class is VERY interesting; i loved the material, though there is a lot of reading. you have to go to class because she doesn't post her power points; the notes are very helpful and the exam is heavier on lecture than on readings. you have to study a lot for the exams but they're pretty straight-forward (multiple choice, t/f)

PHIL 1740.comment: Her lectures are very fun as she is a great lecturer and keeps the class involved through questions and hypotheticals. Since there isn't much that goes toward the grade and it's philosophy, you're more likely to get an A- or below as there is no clear rubric for the papers and exams besides vague information given by the TA's.

Professor Stangl is amazing. Her lectures are not mandatory for this class but they are so captivating and interesting that going is definitely worth it. If you are into ethics then this class is heaven. She has great energy and very passionate about the subject matter. I would take this class again if I could. overal 100/10

Stangl's lectures were really interesting and really useful. Everything she said and put on the board in class was on the tests, so if you don't understand the readings, attend lecture and you'll be set! One of the most thought provoking classes I've had.
He is hot and interesting. Great class material and fair grading. I recommend this class!

PHIL 1700.comment: Class was really easy but putting up with Stangl's lectures for an entire semester was painful at best. She has a bad habit of going off on tangents that shes convinced are really funny (like talking about her cats for a half hour)

STAT 5170.comment: Class  (Stat 5170) is boring and easy, I felt like I learnt more in AP Statistics. UVA Stats is not very good in general

Good class, although somewhat boring.  Professor Woo is really easy compared to other statistic class.  I would say it is one of the few easy A classes as UVa.  But make sure it is him, not other professors.  Otherwise, this is not applicable.

I took his stat 5120 last semester and it was great. There were lots of practical labs and really made me learn a lot. And Jeff is extremely helpful.(in his office almost all the time). stat 5170 is less interesting but still a good class.
Not organized. Hard to understand. Doesn't care about the class whatsoever. Just avoid!!!!!

BIOL 4250.comment: Worst class I've taken at UVA. Earning an A in BIOL3010, I thought BIOL4250 wouldn't be bad. Lectures make no sense, multiple extra lectures are added due to poor time management, 4-hour abstract exams, prof rarely responds to emails if ever, & grades are a mystery (you receive 0 feedback or grades; only a final grade) Hard work doesn't pay off.

BIOL 4050.comment: Tough class; not an easy A. He goes through a lot of material not in the book and tests are all essay-format. I recommend taping the lectures since he tends to go fast. Worst part was he never had office hours and waited weeks before posting slides. Make sure you know what you are getting yourself into...

MSE 3101.comment: Boring and doesn't care if his students learn

LNGS 3250.comment: NOT the first linguistics class that you should take for linguistics at UVA - grade suffered because of it. Lectures are very dry unless interested in the topic, but content is relatively interesting. Course/assignment objectives unclear, although during office hours, professor will give out the assignments' answers. Not accessible on final.

Decent professor. The only notes he gives are in-class handouts, so class is mandatory or you don't get the info. We could miss up to 3 classes, but he doesn't take attendance every class. Assignments are ambiguous, but he's mostly checking that you have the main idea and you tried. Not a hard class if you show up and somewhat pay attention.

Elson is an old-school professor who is very organized and knowledgeable. The subject can be dry if you are not that into linguistics. Expectations on homework were somewhat unclear., but it's not hard to get a decent grade, and the workload is low. We basically just had to do 4 assignments and a take-home final.

Definitely means business in regards to his cell phone policy. Used the phrase "cell phones off and away please" a dozen times every class. He seems intimidating, but he's not so bad. The class is mixed with a graduate level course, so definitely not an easy A (or B). I didn't take the discussion section, and I suffered because of it.
Old School, but remarkably intelligent. Expects his students to be adults. Will need to go to office hours to get above a B.

"Cell phone OFF AND AWAY"- Elson everyday. Obey it. Otherwise, it's a good class if you're interested in Linguistics. If you go to his office hours you'll see how WILLING he is to make sure you understand the material! Even in class he shows it. He's funny how he goes on his tangents but tangents are created for you to relax :)

Intro to Linguistics with Elson was good - he is a prickly old guy, but he has a sense of humor and I don't believe he could truly dislike a student. Show up, turn your phone off, and do the work. Be attentive and neat, and you'll do fine. He definitely cares about the subject and the students. He'll help you understand; that's what he's there for.

LNGS 2240.comment: Professor Elson is extremely knowledgeable and passionate about linguistics. You need to attend class to understand the material, especially if you've never taken a linguistics course or aren't that interested in it (like me). Graded on two take-home tests and a final. As long as you put in effort it's not a difficult class.

Professor Elson was a horribel lecturer and his whole class was lecturing. He did not offer many opportunities for students to include their own thoughts or talk to other classmates about the content. I did not do a single reading and think that I am going to get an A in the class. All 3 assignments in the class were take home tests that were easy.

RUSS 1016.comment: Tough-love type, likes old school pedagogy, and grades are based on improvement and effort- but he's not for everyone. He's very opinionated and will go off on random tangents. Sometimes it's endearing, sometimes you want to tear your hair out. You'll learn A LOT but your enjoyment will depend on how well you tolerate the tangents.

RUSS 5030.comment: Very crabby and sometimes acts like he is the smartest guy in the world, but he definitely knows what he is talking about. He takes all your notes for you and just wants to teach - doesn't care about grades. He will give you an A or A- based just on how you've improved/learned the course material. Take for easy A, but can be tough to sit through

ENWR 1530.comment: This class is a great ENWR class. It is very lecture heavy so make sure you show up to understand the writing assignments. There are three unit essays that are very open to your interpretation. The material covered is very interesting and the group discussions help to understand them better. As long as you follow the models you will do fine.

GSVS 2050.comment: Course is now listed as STS 2050 (Sustainable Energy Systems). I originally took this class hoping for a "GPA Booster" but I ended up having to work really hard for an A. The course itself is very interesting but there were 10-14 articles/podcasts a week with a weekly reading quiz. The quiz was 8 min and open note so take good notes on readings.

Saw bad reviews and figured it was just university students complaining for no reason. Overall, they are right. Unreasonable amount of work given to you outside of class. Lots of the papers and podcasts could easily have been skipped. Avoid this class if possible as it will just take up a lot of your time with busy work.

Really easy to get a B, not reasonable to get an A. Great guy, loves to teach and help, but lecture is often super boring. He puts all the lecture notes online, so if you really have to mis class all you have to do is talk to him. Otherwise, though, you should go to class since he often counts attendance as participation.

ENGR 1520.comment: ENGR 1520 is a dual enrollment class designed mostly for high schoolers. It's probably not what you expect it to be. Expect a lot of busy work with confusing instructions.

ASTR 1290.comment: He is very passionate about astronomy, and his classes are interesting. He also gives out studying material before each quiz, and it is really helpful. 10000% recommend his class

This class covered some complicated themes but Professor Davis was excellent at covering them in short lectures. He was regularly available if you needed help. There are textbook readings but you did not need to complete them to understand the topics. You do need to pay attention in lectures and do the homework to do well, though (it's not hard).

This class is very lecture-heavy but easy to manage.  Professor Davis was available after class (if he had a minute) or during office hours. I would recommend attending lectures because they are interesting! I found it impressive how Prof. Davis condensed complicated topics into short lectures.

He's the nicest guy and you can tell he's so knowledgeable and passionate about astrophysics. I took this course simply for credit and was so happy that I did. Use the study guide for tests and you're all set. Overall a great class to take!

Easily one of my favorite profs of first semester. Shane gives awesome lectures, is clearly passionate, and quizzes and final are straight from lectures, so make sure you read them. I joined this class two weeks late and copped an A- so for most people if you study well you will do fine. Black Holes is a must-take with SHANE!

Shane is the man!! Material can be complicated at first glance but ur boy Shane will get u through it. I just took this class for the lols as a first year looking to take some interesting classes, and I would def recommend. Not all black holes -- lots of other physics/astr stuff, but all good. Office hours are 10/10, study a bit & ur good.

ASTR 1559.comment: I took Black Holes with him, it was a really easy class but still interesting. He is a great guy, very funny and gives good lectures. Would definitely recommend

First things first, this class is the Black Holes class (since ASTR 1559 is the mnemonic for new classes or classes that are irregularly taught).   Prof. Davis is honestly the best professor I have had at UVA. He was able to explain complex topics with ease and made this course very exciting. He was clearly passionate about what he was teaching,

ENGR 1010.comment: Professor Williams was an amazing professor, both kind and caring. She explained things as needed and was always respectful. The course is majority of group projects and some individual assignments that are essentially prerequisites to the three main projects. She was also lenient on grading, though to make sure to follow the rubric closely.

Deep clearly has a passion for this work and clearly tries to help students in every way he can. However, the class structure is completely jumbled. One day he's giving a meaningless lecture, the next you're in a random group with a week to do a project together, then there's a guest speaker, etc.. More homework than expected, but not unmanageable.

ANTH 2559.comment: One of the best professors at UVA. He cares about all of his students. This class was amazing, too; it is structured well, and you learn a lot of history. There are no exams. Just discussion questions, three papers and a final project. If you put in the effort, it's an easy A. Do yourself a favor and take this professor and his classes.

Ok class, subject not very interesting. If you really need to fulfill the archeology requirement, I guess this is the easiest one (since it has not discussions and no papers due.) McCarty is a nice person, and I like the class structure. However,I thought the cut off for an A was unnecessarily harsh. Despite that, I still recommend the class.

McCarty's nice and pretty funny too. Reading is not really necessary although she says it is.  For the tests, just study her powerpoints thoroughly. She brings in food fairly often and offers A LOT of extra credit, so take advantage of it.  Overall, I was not very interested in the subject matter, but it was worth taking the class.
Awesome person, and she is super funny. Her grading is fair too, and it's really not that hard. 3 Major essays and weekly response paper to a topic. its not that hard to do!

Allison Alexy is an amazing professor. I came into the course with essentially no interest in the material, but I'm ending this semester without a doubt in my mind that her course was one of the best I've taken at UVa. She's awesome, funny and an great resource. I've recommended her course to several friends already because I've learned a lot.
I loved this class. It was really easy. Professor may be boring, but overall, quite fair.

He really knows what he is talking about and is very approachable. However, his lectures are a bit boring and therefore hard to follow. But all in all, a good course that I recommend to those interested.

the first professor i've ever had be outright rude and unhelpful. readings were long and dry and we were frequently quizzed. he really isn't interested in helping you learn if you have any difficulties.

He just started teaching this semester. His knowledge is incredible, he just needs to learn how to present it... Rarely uses visual aids and sometimes talks too fast. Really interesting demonstrative lectures (showed us stonemapping with obsidian!), but very dry theory lectures. My guess is as he gets more experienced his lectures will get better.

ECON 3030.comment: This course was sneaky. I felt that the course was easy, until the second exam. From what I've heard he purposefully makes it hard to divide the class. His lectures became disorganized as the semester went on, making what we were supposed to be learning not clear. He offered EC. The final was very hard, and we didn't go over some topics.

He's not an awful professor but he doesn't really teach the material. He simply goes through the slides and breezes over everything as if it were simple, yet his exams are difficult and confusing.  He is obviously well versed in his professional career but he just doesn't teach this class well.

Doyle is a difficult prof for Money and Banking. The average for the first exam was an 69%. To be fair, the class itself is very difficult. However, Carter Doyle a lot of times will gloss quickly over material and then test you on the smallest details. Don't take this class if you have a choice. Also, the textbook is super confusing.

Doyle is extremely friendly and approachable. Took Money and Banking with him, he is very well versed in the material as he was a fortune 500 banker in his previous life. Loves what he does and is approachable during office hours and after class. Encourages you to come to him if you're struggling. Tests aren't too bad either

Prof. Doyle gives good outside examples during his lectures, in fact every test has a take home portion which makes you apply what you learned in class to real world problems. The one problem is that when you get to the test, if you have not read the book the average student could not get an A on the test without reading through the book.

ARH 1010.comment: Took this class because i was genuinely interested in architectural history but the professor ruined that. She is very passive aggressive and condescending to students during lecture and not a very effective lecturer. Most relevant content is said during lecture and not found in the slides or resources. Grading is harsh, subjective and unreasonable

Overall was not a good class to be in. For an intro class I thought it would be a little easier but with the only 3 assignments counting towards our grade being the midterm, paper, and final, there really isn't much room to succeed. Just learn the monuments and terms and you should be able to succeed in this type of class.

Don't recommend if you're taking optionally. Mrs. Reilly didn't inspire or improve my understanding of Arch History. She reads from a script and can often be passive aggressive, snappy, and demeaning to students. She's more understanding during OH though. In short, all you need is to research the monument list on your own. Also, no devices allowed.

I skipped most lectures, never did any of the readings, but memorized the monument list and still passed. Reilly's lectures lacked any enthusiasm and my TA for discussion was okay at best, but I did not put much effort into this course either. Definitely not a course I would recommend for people who are not passionate about the subject.

The most important thing is that you show up to lecture. Pretty much all of the material you need to know for the exams will be covered during the lectures. The readings are pretty much optional. There is also a final paper and weekly reading "quizzes." It does not matter what you score on the quizzes because you get full credit for just doing it.

Lectures are intriguing and Professor Reilly clearly has so much passion for the subject. Section counts as a huge part of the grade so pray for a good TA, but Professor Reilly is nothing but great. She can be sarcastic from time to time, though when I visited her office hours she was really sweet.

Professor Reilly can tend to be passive aggressive towards students when asked questions. Lectures also are very boring, she reads from a script which make the lectures non engaging. Having a good TA is key for this class as everything is essay based. Be sure to attend sections as those are a huge part of your grade.

Lectures are boring and you could learn more from the textbook, but go because there are random in class turned in assignments to make sure you attend. Tests are pure memorization and are easy if you study/have good notes/ or read the textbook. She's not super approachable, and class could be so much more interesting than she makes it, but its ok

Not approachable, can be sarcastic and a bit rude. Be careful of falling asleep or asking a stupid question. Lectures are interesting and instructions are clear, do not ask stupid questions. Tests are tough but TA grades them, find one that you like and get to know their grading style. Impromptu in-class check-ins, go to class and section.

CE 3300.comment: Had a good time in this class. Professor was laid back, lectured well, and made content easy to understand. Occasionally he would review old content too slowly but it wasn't always a bad thing. The class felt the perfect level of challenging. Group project felt unnecessary but was a good opportunity to use and learn SAP2000 software.

ANTH 2270.comment: Before considering taking this professor, don't. She was consistently late to classes, would constantly have errors in lecture slides, including misspellings and formatting errors, or just wrong information. Discussion section was what made this class passable. Material was easy, but her teaching abilities are abhorrent, UVA should reevaluate.

It was very clear that she did not put the time or effort in to teaching. There were numerous typos in every lecture, study guide, rubric, and test. This made it incredibly hard to learn and felt disrespectful of our time and money. She rambles a lot and the lectures are not very helpful. All of the tests are based solely on the readings.

Rambles a lot and has lectures that are really hard to follow because they don't have a clear structure. Most of the assignments are unclear and we are 80% done with the semester and we have no grades in the gradebook. She's often late to class and going to class just feels like a waste of time.

ANTH 3590.comment: I think the subject matter was absolutely wonderful, but her teaching lowered the quality of this class. This class had wasted potential, due to her being late on numerous occasions to class, several typos in the syllabus and other assignment, grades being put in days before they are due, and her rambling and not making much sense a lot of times.

Professor Fraser didn't even know what she was talking about half the time, she would refer questions asked by students back to other students because she was constantly unsure.  She seemed to be learning along WITH the class versus teaching it, while the exams were extremely specific and harsh grading.

Professor Fraser would come in to class and would forget what the reading was about and have to ask students. Her powerpoints are full of misspellings and look very thrown together and the assignments she gives are unhelpful in learning the material. She seems to be learning it along with us.

SOC 2052.comment: I cannot say enough good things about him. Out of all of the classes I have taken at UVA, his sociology of the family class is one that truly can be applied to the real world in the best way possible. I found myself looking forward going to lecture every class. The readings are great, and if you make an effort, you will likely get an A. 11/10.

i took soc of family to get a credit out of the way, and it was a pretty easy class. there is discussion, midterm and final, and an 8 pg paper but i did none of the reading and got an a. some of his politics are flawed but its an overall easy a

Sociology of the family is a great class. Very easy to get an A in, barely any homework. Like any class, participation matters. Material is interesting and extremely relevant. Anyone who gives Wilcox a poor rating is only kidding themselves and you. They probably just don't agree with his politics. But you don't have to in order to enjoy the class.

Soc of the family is a super easy class. You don't need to do the reading, but you should know which ones go to which topic because you need to quote them on tests. Hands out mc answers in lectures. All the information you need will be in the lectures. Class is extremely interesting.

I took this expecting an easy A but was the only B I got. Tests are ridiculous because half is essays where you have to give specific facts and cite the exact readings they come from. Lecture is not an acceptable source (even though he cites his own books) No feedback on the 8 page essay. Wilcox is a fair guy but requires too much pointless effort.
I loved this class! The lectures can get long, and you show up to your discussion section because it helps clear up confusing subjects that are covered during lecture.

SOC 2052 was the easiest class that I've taken at UVA thus far. Professor Wilcox is very nice but very repetitive. The lectures are really boring and you are forced to go due to I-clicker participation questions but the class is very  easy. Lots of reading but I didn't do any of it and still managed to get an A in the class.

Wilcox seems to really dislike women and any person of color, according to his lectures. A professor like this would only be allowed to run rampant like this in a predominantly white, male-dominated school like UVA. I've really like sociology so far, but Wilcox's comments really offended me.

Dr. Wilcox is a nice man. I hated his class though. To put it diplomatically, I would say he has trouble seeing both sides of an issue and doesn't use very reliable statistics. He is very conservative and stubborn. Not a bad guy, but maybe not the best class for a liberal woman.

Best class I took at UVA. Didn't do any of the readings and still got an A. Just go to lecture and you'll be fine. The material is interesting and you can connect to it. Make sure to take the class with him. I heard the other lady that teaches it isn't as good
Wilcox is great. There is a lot of reading but he goes over much of it in lecture, so not all of it is necessary. Exams and papers are straightforward, if you attend lecture you will be fine.

Her lectures relied heavily on the readings, and her lecture slides are pretty ambiguous without context, so if you join late or miss a lecture, you're gonna need to borrow notes, especially since she does not provide the lecture slides for studying/reviewing purposes. The only assignments are essays and participation in your TA discussion section.

Professor Pugh is a big lecturer and loves to assign readings. My advice is do the reading before class and take notes so you're ready for the lecture. It makes a lot more sense this way. You will probably interact with your TA much more than Professor Pugh but the class is interesting and not too intense. It helps if this subject interests you.

Professor Pugh seems to love her sociology, but her setup of the course was questionable. The required readings consisted of her own book as well as her friends' books from graduate school. Had daily iClicker questions and flies through her powerpoint slides. She assigned 5 papers on the weekly (long) readings, a 6-page essay, and an 8-page essay.

This course has been changed extremely from how Pugh used to teach it in the past. There are 19 i-clicker quizzes given in lecture so there is basically a quiz 75% of the time. You actually have to do the reading and read it well to get a decent grade on the quizzes and frequently i would read thoroughly and do poorly.

She is very interactive during lectures, and likes to check what you're doing on your computer, but she really just wants people to participate and doesn't mind a different opinion if you can back it up

Opens her lectures w/ lots of (unnecessary) statistics, but she makes sure to pinpoint the main ideas/arguments of the EXTENSIVE readings. Uses clickers to monitor attendance. Gives exam ?s prior to exam where you can use notes and Internet to prepare. Great readings.  Take-home final that's pretty fair--you can use your notes, too! Skim read

Prof Pugh is not boring but also not that engaging. Her lectures often reiterate what you have already read. There is a lot of reading and many assignments but it's honestly a very easy class! I thought the topic was interesting too.
If you want an easyish A, don't take. If you need to take this class, take it when Will Cox teaches it. He's more interesting. Lectures = boring, says everyone. Unless you LOVE Soc.
loved this class!

SOC 4052.comment: He really is a great man and really invests in his students.  You can tell he knows his stuff and is really smart but lectures are little dry.  An insane amount of reading but can get by without doing it as long as you answer personal questions in class to get participation. Had us over for dinner and was so great!

ASTR 2110.comment: This is the only class that has ever pushed me to write a review on here. Questions on problem sets and tests are extremely vague, instructions are counter-intuitive, and no matter what you will be graded extremely harshly. Very little feedback is given for where you went wrong. Professor Skrutskie is great, but this class is simply not worth it.

I took ASTR 2110 in the fall of 2022, and I feel it is necessary that I post this review after seeing all of the recent 1/5 reviews. I do not understand where they are coming from. Professor Skrutskie was the best professor I have ever had. He was engaging and genuinely cared about his students. Don't be dissuaded by the recent negative reviews.

AST 2110 left much to be desired. The grading system was cryptic, lacking clear criteria and transparent instructions. Students struggled to understand how their efforts were being evaluated, creating a frustrating and confusing learning experience. Approach with caution if you value a straightforward approach to assessments.

I got 100% on every assignment except for the exams, which were confusingly graded and much more difficult than lecture material. We were given 2 hours to complete them, but honestly the questions asked would take 5+.
Overally disorganized and it was a very exhausting class. Problem sets were very confusing, not well explained, and TA was not insightful even though they wrote the problem set.

Not ever clear with how to solve problems or actually do the math behind the equations, covers extraneous components for the class period, then tests you on stuff never actually covered.

The best way I would describe it: He shows you how to get from A to B and the K to J and then he expects you to know A to Z.

Is not clear on expectations when grading, could say he wants you to be precise, but then will take off points if you don't write enough/exactly what he says- very frustrating especially when exams are worth 55% of the final grade.

If he says write briefly, write a lot. If he says make crude approximations, you need to show every step in that process while not ever using sig figs as those will get points taken off. If you don't use sig figs sometimes, he will also mark you off. According to him, and literally no one else in the department, Pi is 3 and e is just Pi.

Exams are 55% of your grade, so if you mess those up, you have no chance getting an A. Very unclear on why so many points are deducted on exams. If you don't write enough to his satisfaction, he will mark you off, but answers should be very brief. The whole course was very conflicted as he asks for one thing, then expects the opposite.

Very unclear grading parameters, tests worth a disproportionately large chunk of the final grade. Problem sets often are beyond the scope of things explained in the lecture, their difficulty largely depends on how good the discussion section TA is. Overall disconnect between the lectures and the graded assignments.

CAS 2150.comment: Love this professor so clear on everything he asked for and he gave unlimited attempts on quizzes such a nice person 10/10 recommend.

PLAP 4500.comment: Prof Cary is the best!! all-around awesome person and amazing instructor w/ funny and inspirational personal anecdotes about her time as a presidential speech writer. Brought in a ton of amazing guest speakers (both from the right and left), and goes out of her way to be bipartisan. Really cares for students. Deserves all the accolades.

Professor Cary is by far my favorite professor Ive had at UVA. I took PLAP 4500: Speechwriting with her in the Fall of 2019 and she made every class unique and useful. Her knowledge on speechwriting is unmatched and the guest speakers she brought in were very esteemed. She is an absolute delight and very passionate about helping her students grow.
Great Discussion, very passionate about student's success

Overall enjoyable class.  I think it is his first time teaching this particular course so he was a little bit rusty at times but clearly is extremely insightful and is a great lecturer.    Haven't finished the course yet but it seems like he's pretty chill about grading.  Definitely recommend the class if he teaches it again.

He showed rudimentary knowledge of the course, occasionally deferring to students when creating GIS models for lack of understanding. He brings absolutely no enthusiasm at all, which is an enormous problem in a two and a half hour seminar. He lectured on irrelevant information and tested based upon this information, OVERALL DISAPOINTED

Fair professor.  A lot of reading.  He is very knowledgeable and passionate about Virginia State Elections.  The GIS mapping is actually interesting and he is more than willing to help outside of classroom hours with projects etc.

I took his class on VA elections. Krom def expected us to complete the heavy reading load, but it was worth it bec. it allowed us to have some enlightening discussions. A pretty easy seminar all things considered-just 3 two-pg summaries, 3 quizzes, and a 5-pg paper- but he does expect a huge group project at the end relying heavily on GIS data.

PSYC 2100.comment: Surprisingly, for someone who conducts research in behavior and learning, he does not apply any of it to teaching the class. He can also be rude and demeaning after initially coming off as nice, which was a bit of a shock at first. It's clear that he looks down on students and does not care about their success.

manz is a SUPER hard grader, but his class is passable. he's actually a funny person and his lectures are interesting because he is very into the topics but that makes the content a bit harder to absorb. his lectures are also very heavy so take good notes. the tests are very based on the slides themselves

DO NOT TAKE. Worst class I've taken at UVA by far. Any answer that is not word for word what he wants is graded as wrong on the exams. He was also mean and unhelpful during office hours. Extremely difficult to get a good grade.

I don't recommend anybody to take this class from this Prof. He plays in the life of students. He tells you in the beginning that he wants you to succeed, but that is not true; he works hard to test you to fail you.

Do not take this class. He tests you on how he knows the material, not on the material itself. This means be ready for tricky questions that do not measure your knowledge, only how well you can jump through hoops.

This class is very hard to get a good grade in, and I don't think I'd recommend it to non-psych majors. I took it in my first semester of my first year and it was honestly a mistake. HOWEVER! I've got to admitI really liked this class. I really learned a lot from Williams, and though he's tough on your grade, he's worth considering.

DO NOT take this class, unless you absolutely have to. I worked as hard as I possibly could and I did not even come close to doing well in this class. Not helpful, Doesn't care about your grade. Only talks about sections of the brain and the tests are basically straight memorization. Not a conceptual class in any way

I absolutely loved Professor Williams as a person, but he was the toughest professor I have ever had. He is hilarious, kind, caring, and his lectures are interesting. However, he packs so much information into every single lecture that if you look away for even a second its like you're now a couple slides behind. SO MUCH MEMORIZATION

Terrible. horrible. Do NOT take this class. The only way you can hope to get even a B is if you memorize everything from lectures, pointless diagrams, and the book. Seriously memorize EVERYTHING or you are screwed. Williams knows his stuff but doesn't know how to teach it.
Hard and unhelpful.  Would not take again.

This class was VERY difficult. Unless you enjoy detailed behavioral sciences, I would not take this class. Lectures are long and information PACKED; I found every lecture session to be very overwhelming. You have to memorize EVERYTHING for the tests.

He's really funny and I enjoyed the class. I am the type of student that would never miss a class and would always do HW. but this class was extremely impossible to get an A on. IT WAS HARD!  He's a great person and a professor but ID NEVER want to take this class again. 2000+ level? More like 4000 : Oh and theres 4 long papers :(

Professor Williams was incredibly interesting and funny. I was never bored in his class. He had review sessions before tests where he'd answer any questions.  Still, the tests were impossible to get an A on. There were five papers that were graded very easily. You really don't have to read the book at all. I loved this class!

His style of teaching is useless. He tries to incorporate elements of learning psychology into his ppts but doesn't include really any info he says in lecture on them. He puts pictures of his slides on exams and expects answers exactly as he says them in lecture. Just make sure you go above and beyond on homework. ALSO, YOU HAVE TO GO TO CLASS!

Dr. Williams is a great professor and very invested in his work, but this class is close-to-impossible. The material is really interesting, but even if you attend every class and take vigorous notes, you're by no means guaranteed to do well whatsoever. This is a lot more medical-based Psych than Social, so I struggled a lot.

Quite literally one of the best professors I've had at UVa so far. I took this class my first semester at UVa, and if you go to class, do your homework, go to office hours and don't wait to get help, you're GUARANTEED an A. It does have some neurobiology, but nothing that can't be handled. Also makes himself available on appointment. Amazing class!

Pretty cool teacher and at first I thought the info would be boring, but if you pay attention, it's really neat. He goes really fast so you have to keep up. Tests are multiple choice and short answer, which can be tough, depending on how much you study. But I liked it and pretty well.

PLAN 1010.comment: If you need 3 credits, take this class. More than that, Tim Beatley is a national treasure. He loves biophilia, birds, and the Cheong-gye-cheon River. Every class is a new adventure, and you do learn how to think imaginatively and tackle concerning urban issues. There's no homework except a big paper; all you need is to pay attention & you'll pass.
Amazing class, amazing teacher, definitely take this class even if you aren't in the A-School.

Really nice guy, who is clearly passionate about his work, but his lectures can get pretty slow and rambly. His takes on planning can also get kind of weird- you'll spend just as much if not more time talking about birds flying into windows than you will the housing crisis. Overall though the course is pretty easy.

I adored having Beatley, he is so passionate about what he's teaching and truly made me consider going into urban planning. While he records all lectures, it is not necessary to go over each one as a lot of the content is repetitive. Final grade is made up of two exams, which are just memorizing terms, and a paper that you have months to work on.

Beatley is a very cool guy and passionate about this subject. Took this class as a non-architecture major and enjoyed it. Graded on two tests and one big paper so give yourself time to do it. The tests are basically memorization as well. No need to attend lectures or do the reading if you don't want to. Just memorize and work on the paper.

Dont buy the books. I didnt read one chapter and did well. He gives you study guides for the midterm and final. You also write one paper. I got a B because I didnt do that well on the paper. He is a great lecturer. Hes passionate about teaching intro level classes. The content of his class is interesting and every lecture taught me so much!

You can tell he is a genuine guy, but his lectures are very boring and not very helpful. Tests are pretty easy, graded fairly difficult. Make sure to give yourself plenty of time for the big paper. Only take this class if it is a requirement, otherwise, you won't get much out of it.

Tim Beatley actually has some very interesting lectures and uses a bunch of unique examples (which show up on the exams). If you show up to them and are half awake, you should do fine. Textbook is unnecessary.

No need to buy textbooks or do any of the readings unless you want to. He gives out a review guide that covers most of the tests, but going to class can help with understanding the bigger concepts not on the review guide. Beatley is clearly very passionate about planning, which makes some of the lectures fairly interesting.

Easy class - hardly went. Don't buy the textbooks. If you attend class and pay attention, you will do great. If not, you will still do well if you study on your own. Many study guides on quizlet from prev yrs helped. Paper, midterm, final are fairly easy. He's a cool guy, but the class is so lax - can be super cool though and interesting material.

Awesome guy, just not the best professor. Class topic is interesting but lectures aren't so much. Only 3 grades, two tests and a large paper. If you attend class and study, no problem, otherwise study smart. Great for ARCH majors.

PLAN 1030.comment: Do not take his class. He makes an interesting subject and turns it extremely boring.

He's very passionate about the subject and it's easy to tell through his many somewhat unrelated stories. No need to do the readings. The exams are relatively easy and the paper is graded fairly easy too

Beatley is a wonderful professor. He is passionate about his field and truly cares about getting his students to love it too. The material is very interesting and had me considering a transfer into the A-school.

PLAN 5810.comment: Wonderful professor passionate about urban and environmental planning. Shares lots of anecdotes and photographs.

SATR 3350.comment: He's a kind professor who encourages many upbeat discussions in class. The class is very relaxed, and everyone jokes around. He is truly passionate about the topic and can answer pretty much anything, or is willing to go through the research to provide an answer. It is not lecture heavy, and the readings are easily digestible.

MESA 3345.comment: I would be extremely wary of taking any of Professor Nair's classes. He gets super behind and by the end of the semester you've got all the work that has been pushed back from the start of the semester. He also doesn't return grades on time, and is very late with them. Unless you  like writing paper on paper on paper, DO NOT take the class.

RELI 2070.comment: Took Classical Islam and it was wonderful! He is very insightful and the lectures were interesting. There were no weekly discussion posts, or small tedious assignments. our grades are compiled from 4-5 total assignments, but aren't too bad. If you need any extensions or help with any course work, he'll definitely help you out!!

Class/professor were really interesting. Most professors aren't willing to admit that he/she doesn't know the answer to a question, but Al-Rahim doesn't hesitate to look up a question you have. Exams can be tough, but he gives a study guide. Don't do the tons of assigned readings because he clarifies in class. Take this class for NW perspective.

Al-Rahim is awesome! I had fun in this class because I was interested in the material. He's not difficult. Grades are based on participation, midterm, and a final (sometimes gives extra credit). The exams weren't hard; he gave a study guide and vocab list. In our class, if you didn't do well, you were probably too lazy to make a study guide.

You can basically absorb the religion of islam by looking at him and listening to him talk.  But don't expect to actually learn from his lectures all that much.  He isn't the clearest explainer, and this really hurts when talking about a subject inscrutable as islam.  Reading the books and wikipediaing the terms is the best way to go

This was by far the most boring and worst class I have ever taken at the University. The professor rambles on aimlessly, schedules 2 hour "make up" classes at night when he misses class, and yells at students. The readings are just as cryptic as the professor. Never take this class.

RELI 2085.comment: I learned a lot in this class. Professor Nair is a really intelligent, friendly guy. However, he can sometimes be long-winded in his lectures and tends to get sidetracked, which can make things a little confusing. There's quite a bit of reading assigned, but the overall workload is pretty light.

HILA 3021.comment: Loved this class. Not only was it incredibly interesting, but the workload was very manageable, which made it much easier to actually pay attention to the class and engage, instead of just worry about getting a good grade. The lectures were very insightful, out of class readings and videos as well. Few assignments, 2 papers and 4 short responses.

RELH 2090.comment: I didn't really understand his lectures because it seemed like he just rambled during class, discussion attendance is mandatory but I honestly learned more in discussion than in class. Overall there isn't a lot of work but there's a lot of memorization. Reading is recommended but not required to do well in the class, just know the general ideas.
Lots of reading that I didn't do all of, learned a lot, lectures get off topic a lot but it's mostly fun.

Lectures are strictly verbal, no powerpoint.  You have to come to class and take notes in order to have what you need for the exams.  He does a pretty detailed in-class review before the exams and often hints at things that will be on the test.  You don't need to do the readings but the paper does require use of one of the books.

Nemec should get a promotion if that is possible, as long as that still means he is teaching. Easily one of the best lecturers I've ever seen. He has a passion for Hinduism and India in general. He engaged me in a manner that made me want to learn more.
Amazing teacher! I am always interested in going to class and he gives brilliant fluid lectures that easily convey difficult concepts. He is funny and energized. TAKE HIS CLASS!

RELH 3440.comment: TAKE THIS CLASS, EVEN IF YOU ARE NOT A RELIGION MAJOR. This is my favorite class that I've ever taken at UVa, and it's not even close. Nemec is knowledgeable, funny, and you can tell he really wants his students to succeed inside and outside of the classroom. The class is only graded by 3 papers, but as long as you try, you'll be fine.

RELG 1040.comment: John Nemec is one of my favorite professors at UVA. I have taken two of his classes, and I would honestly take a third. He is really passionate about the religions he teaches, and he makes class interesting. I highly recommend him, and it was not very challenging of a course.
